column1: ;Explain why isobenzofuran (shown below) is a particularly reactive diene compound in the Diels-Alder reaction. Write the product of its reaction with cyclohexene.;;;data/images/670880520ed68fbdc467064e_2.png;"Reactivity of Isobenzofuran as a Diene

Isobenzofuran is exceptionally reactive as a diene in the Diels-Alder reaction because the products it forms upon [4+2] cycloaddition with a dienophile possess a fully aromatic benzene ring that is entirely stabilized by resonance.
In isobenzofuran itself
column2: the benzene ring is not fully aromatic — it is fused to the furan in a way that disrupts complete aromaticity. However
column3: when the furan portion acts as the diene and undergoes the Diels-Alder cycloaddition
column4: the fused six-membered ring regains full aromatic character. This restoration of aromaticity provides a strong thermodynamic driving force
column5: making isobenzofuran an exceptionally reactive diene.

column1: Product of the Reaction with Cyclohexene
When isobenzofuran reacts with cyclohexene (acting as the dienophile) in a Diels-Alder reaction
column2: the product is:
4-Epoxy-1
column3: 4-dihydro-1
column4: 4-ethanonaphthalene fused with cyclohexane — more specifically
column5: it is a bridged bicyclic compound where:

column1: The furan diene system has undergone [4+2] cycloaddition across the double bond of cyclohexene.
An oxygen bridge is present (from the furan oxygen).
The resulting product contains a fully aromatic benzene ring fused to the newly formed bridged bicyclic system incorporating the cyclohexane ring.
The two new C–C bonds formed are at the bridgehead positions
column2: and the bridgehead hydrogens are on the same face (endo/exo)
column3: consistent with the stereochemistry of the Diels-Alder reaction (cis addition).

column1: The product is essentially a 1
column2: 4-epoxy-1
column6: 4a
column12: 4-methanonaphthalene framework — a tricyclic oxygen-bridged structure with a restored aromatic ring.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;670880520ed68fbdc467064e;TRUE;1

column1: ;What is the product from this reaction?;;;data/images/670880520ed68fbdc467064e_3.png;"Reaction Description
The starting material is a furan derivative bearing two substituents: a methyl group and a prenyl-type (3-methylbut-2-enyl) side chain.
When this compound is treated with ZnCl₂ (0.5 equivalents) in decalin at 140°C for 9 hours
column2: the reaction proceeds through an intramolecular Diels-Alder reaction where the furan acts as the diene.

column1: Product

The initial Diels-Alder cycloaddition product is an oxygen-bridged bicyclic intermediate — the expected intramolecular [4+2] cycloaddition product where the furan diene reacts with the pendant alkene (dienophile) in the side chain.
However
column2: under these Lewis acid-catalyzed conditions (ZnCl₂)
column3: this intermediate does not stop there. It undergoes a subsequent rearrangement and cyclization
column4: leading to the final product which is a cyclized aromatic compound — specifically a methylated dihydrobenzofuran or indane-type derivative bearing methyl substituents.

column1: Key Observation
In this rearrangement
column2: the product obtained is the derivative resulting from the cyclization of the intermediate
column3: meaning the oxygen bridge opens and rearrangement occurs to restore aromaticity and form a more stable cyclic framework.

column1: In contrast
column2: when the same reaction is performed without catalyst at 220°C in decalin for 19 hours
column3: only the expected (normal) Diels-Alder adduct is obtained — that is
column4: the simple oxygen-bridged bicyclic product without any rearrangement or further cyclization.

column1: Explanation
The ZnCl₂ Lewis acid facilitates the opening of the oxygen bridge in the initial Diels-Alder adduct
column2: promoting a retro-[4+2] or ring-opening/rearrangement pathway that leads to aromatization and cyclization. Without the Lewis acid
column3: the reaction requires higher temperature and longer time
column4: and the intermediate is kinetically stable enough that it does not undergo further rearrangement
column5: giving only the direct Diels-Alder product.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;670880520ed68fbdc467064e;TRUE;2

column1: 67089c013b511a575fc306de;"A series of indium phosphide quantum dots capped with oleate of different sizes are synthesized. The quantum dots are dissolved in 33% hydrochloric acid
column2: and the enthalpy of dissolution is measured. This reaction generates indium (III)
column3: phosphine gas
column4: and a solid oleic acid mass. As the size of the quantum dots decrease
column5: the enthalpy of dissolution becomes more endothermic. The enthalpy of dissolution of bulk indium phosphide is -86 kJ/mol
column6: and the protonation enthalpy of oleate is 7 kJ/mol. The enthalpy of dissolution of the largest quantum dot is 70 kJ/mol of indium phosphide
column7: while the enthalpy of dissolution of the smallest quantum dot is 120 kJ/mol of indium phosphide. The mass fraction oleate is 46% for the largest quantum dot
column8: and 52% for the smallest quantum dot. The molecular weight of indium phosphide is 146 g/mol
column9: and the molecular weight of oleate is 281 g/mol. What is the most logical explanation of this observation?

column1: Answer Choices:
A. With smaller quantum dots more oleate is present
column2: making the dissolution more endothermic due to protonation

column1: B. As the size of the quantum dots decrease
column2: there is less indium phosphide
column3: making the dissolution less exothermic

column1: C. The quantum dots have a negative surface energy making the dissolution more endothermic
D. Organic ligands pack tightly on the surface of quantum dots. Disrupting this ligand shell is endothermic as it breaks inter-ligand interactions
column2: and as smaller quantum dots have a greater proportion of organic ligands
column3: their dissolution becomes more endothermic

column1: E. Surface indium in indium phosphide is in a higher oxidation state than the interior
column2: making the dissolution of greater proportions of surface indium more endothermic";;;;C;multipleChoice;;A negative surface energy would mean the surface atoms are more stable relative to the interior
column3: so dissolving a quantum dot with a greater proportion if surface atoms would lead to a more endothermic dissolution. Smaller quantum dots have a higher proportion of surface atoms
column4: so a negative surface energy explains the trend. While the protonation of oleate is endothermic
column5: the values provided show that protonation cannot explain the observed results. The reported values are in kJ/mol of indium phosphide
column6: so less mass fraction of indium phosphide is irrelevant. The packing of ligands is important
column7: but as mentioned in the beginning
column8: the reaction forms an oleic acid aggregate
column9: which would also have inter-ligand interactions
column10: so no net change in inter-ligand interactions is expected. Indium would not reasonably have a different oxidation state beyond indium (III) in this system
column11: regardless if it was in the interior or on the surface of the quantum dot.;Chemistry;Chemistry;;FALSE;

column1: ;Explain the role of sodium or ammonium oleate in the stabilization of InP quantum dots (QDs) during synthesis and how it influences the final size.;;;;"The oleate (carboxylate ion) acts as a surface ligand
column2: controlling the growth
column3: preventing aggregation
column4: and modulating the optical properties through surface passivation.

column1: More specifically:
Growth control: The oleate ligands bind to the surface of the growing InP nanocrystals
column2: regulating the rate at which monomers add to the surface. This allows for controlled
column3: uniform growth.

column1: Preventing aggregation: The long hydrocarbon chains of the oleate create a steric barrier around each QD
column2: preventing them from coming into contact and fusing together.

column1: Surface passivation: By coordinating to surface indium atoms
column2: the oleate ligands passivate dangling bonds and surface defects
column3: which improves the optical properties (photoluminescence) of the QDs.

column1: Size influence: The concentration of oleate ligand directly affects the final size of the QDs. A higher ligand concentration generally slows growth and leads to smaller particles
column2: while a lower concentration allows faster growth and larger particles.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;;TRUE;1

column1: ;"An InP QD synthesized has a diameter of 3 nm (capped with oleate). Calculate the energy of the fundamental electronic transition (in eV) using the particle-in-a-box model
column2: then compare with a 5 nm QD.

column1: Basic formula:

column3: R^2} \cdot n^2$";;;;"Key Parameters

column1: Planck's constant: h = 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s
Effective mass of the electron in InP: m* ≈ 0.077 × mₑ = 0.077 × 9.109 × 10⁻³¹ kg = 7.01 × 10⁻³² kg
Conversion factor: 1 eV = 1.602 × 10⁻¹⁹ J
For the fundamental transition
Calculation for the 3 nm QD (R = 1.5 nm = 1.5 × 10⁻⁹ m)
$\boxed{E_1 \approx 2.17 \text{ eV} \quad (\text{for } d = 3 \text{ nm})}$
Calculation for the 5 nm QD (R = 2.5 nm = 2.5 × 10⁻⁹ m)
$\boxed{E_1 \approx 0.78 \text{ eV} \quad (\text{for } d = 5 \text{ nm})}$
Comparison and Interpretation
QD DiameterRadiusEnergy (eV)3 nm1.5 nm~2.17 eV5 nm2.5 nm~0.78 eV
The energy decreases as the radius increases
column2: following the 1/R² dependence.

column1: The larger QD (5 nm) has a lower transition energy
column2: corresponding to a longer wavelength of emitted/absorbed light — this is a red shift.

column1: The smaller QD (3 nm) has a higher transition energy
column2: corresponding to a shorter wavelength — this is a blue shift.

column1: This demonstrates the fundamental principle of quantum confinement: as the size of the QD decreases
column2: the energy levels become more widely spaced
column3: increasing the bandgap energy. This is why QD size can be used to tune optical properties across the visible spectrum.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;;TRUE;2

column1: At the desired temperature T₂
column2: the conductivity σ₂ must equal 200 S/m.

Taking the natural logarithm of both sides of equation (2) and rearranging:
Substituting the numerical values of k
column2: E_g

column4: and σ₂:

column1: The desired temperature T₂ is therefore equal to 736.8 K = 464°C.
b) Dopant element to obtain a p-type semiconductor
A p-type extrinsic semiconductor has positive charge carriers
column2: therefore holes (electron vacancies). It is obtained by doping silicon with elements belonging to column III of the periodic table
column3: since these elements have only three valence electrons and
column4: when in solid solution in silicon
column5: will create one hole (one electron vacancy) for each dopant atom.

column1: Suitable dopants: B
column2: Al
column3: Ga
column4: or In

column1: c) Concentration C_A of a p-type dopant to achieve a conductivity of 200 S/m at ambient temperature
According to the problem statement
column2: the conductivity at ambient temperature is provided by the charge carriers of the dopant element
column3: which are holes (electron vacancies). Neglecting the contribution of electrons and holes from intrinsic silicon — since this contribution is very small — we can deduce the number n_h of holes per unit volume (in m³) that the extrinsic silicon must contain to have a conductivity of 200 S/m:

column1: In 1 m³ of silicon
column2: there are n_Si atoms of silicon. This number is obtained if we know the volumetric mass density ρ of silicon (2.33 g/cm³ = 2.33 × 10⁶ g/m³) and the mass m_Si of one atom of silicon
column3: which is equal to the ratio of the molar mass A_Si to Avogadro's number N_A. We obtain:

column1: The atomic concentration C_A of the p-type dopant element is therefore:
(C_A)_p = 0.627 ppm atomic
Remark: We note that a very low doping level is required (less than 1 atomic ppm!) to multiply the conductivity of silicon at ambient temperature by approximately 500
d) Concentration C_A of an n-type dopant to achieve a conductivity of 200 S/m at ambient temperature
When using an n-type dopant element
column2: we simply change the mobility μ to that of the majority charge carriers
column3: which are now electrons. Therefore
column4: from equations (4) and (5)
column5: we can deduce that the n-type dopant concentration (C_A)_n is related to the p-type dopant concentration (C_A)_p by the following relationship:

column1: (C_A)_n / (C_A)_p = μ_h / μ_e
(C_A)_n = 0.172 ppm atomic
Remark: We note that to obtain the same value of extrinsic conductivity
column2: a lower doping level is needed when using an n-type dopant (which contributes to conduction through its extra electrons) compared to using a p-type dopant (which contributes to conduction through its electron vacancies/holes). This is due to the fact that the mobility μ_e of electrons is higher than that of holes μ_h.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;67090fa5356700b5af622ae8;TRUE;1

column1: ;"A copper wire (6 m long
column2: 5.6 mm in diameter)
column3: having a resistivity ρ of 1.54 × 10⁻⁶ Ω·cm at 0°C
column4: is subjected to a potential difference of 0.1 V.

column1: Questions:
a) Calculate how many electrons pass through the cross-section of the wire per second.
b) Knowing that the resistivity ρ at 100°C is equal to 2.22 × 10⁻⁶ Ω·cm
column2: state whether the number of electrons flowing through the wire per second increases or decreases when the temperature of the wire is raised to 100°C. Justify your answer quantitatively.";;;;"a) Number of electrons passing through the cross-section

column1: The number of electrons X₀ flowing per second through the wire at 0°C is given by the following relation:
where I is the current intensity (number of electric charges per second) and e is the elementary electric charge of the electron (1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C).
Equation 9.23 from the textbook gives:
Combining equations (1) and (2)
column2: we obtain:

column1: X₀ = VS / (lρe)     ... (3)
With the given data:
l = 600 cm
We obtain:
X₀ = 1.66 × 10²⁰ electrons/s
b) Direction of change of X₀ when the temperature is raised to 100°C
The number of electrons flowing through the wire decreases
column2: because this number is inversely proportional to the resistivity of the material (equation 3 above). Since the resistivity increases when the temperature rises
column3: fewer electrons flow per second.

column1: The number X₁₀₀ of electrons flowing per second through the wire at 100°C is given by the relation:
X₁₀₀ / X₀ = ρ₀ / ρ₁₀₀
Therefore:
X₁₀₀ = (ρ₀ / ρ₁₀₀) × X₀
X₁₀₀ = 1.15 × 10²⁰ electrons/s
This confirms that the number of electrons passing through the wire per second decreases when the temperature increases from 0°C to 100°C
column2: which is consistent with the fact that resistivity increases with temperature in metals (due to increased lattice vibrations that scatter conduction electrons more frequently).";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;67090fa5356700b5af622ae8;TRUE;2

column1: 670b2be8daac77037b0e67ba;Two pericyclic reactions occur in this thermal transformation. What are the specific reactions involved?;;;data/images/670b2be8daac77037b0e67ba_1.png;4π conrotatory

column1: ;"The following two thermocyclizations are carried out through the intermediacy of enolic forms. Explain by mechanism.

a) A cyclohexanone derivative bearing a pendant alkene chain (hex-5-enyl substituent) is heated at 300°C to yield a bicyclo[2.2.1] bridged ketone (norbornane-type fused bicyclic system with a carbonyl group).
b) A cyclohexanone derivative bearing an exocyclic diene/alkene system is heated at 300°C to yield a fused bicyclic enone product.

This type of synthesis was employed by L. A. Paquette to synthesize fused bicyclic compounds. Explain.";;;data/images/670b2be8daac77037b0e67ba_2.png;"These reactions are thermal cyclic rearrangements (thermal pericyclic reactions).
a) First Reaction
The starting material is a cyclohexanone bearing a pendent hex-5-enyl chain.
Step 1 — Enolization: Upon heating (Δ)
column2: the ketone undergoes thermal tautomerization to form the enol form. This generates a diene system (the enol double bond conjugated with or positioned appropriately relative to the terminal alkene in the side chain).

column1: Step 2 — Intramolecular Diels-Alder reaction: The enol acts as part of the diene component
column2: while the terminal alkene in the side chain serves as the dienophile. An intramolecular [4+2] cycloaddition takes place
column3: forming an oxygen-containing bridged bicyclic intermediate (with the enol oxygen forming part of the bridge).

column1: Step 3 — Tautomerization/Rearrangement: The bridged enol ether intermediate then undergoes ring opening or retro-tautomerization
column2: restoring the carbonyl group. This gives the final product: a bridged bicyclic ketone (norbornane-type framework bearing a ketone functional group).

column1: b) Second Reaction
The starting material is a cyclohexanone bearing an isopropenyl substituent.
Step 1 — Enolization: Upon heating (Δ)
column2: the ketone tautomerizes to its enol form
column3: generating a conjugated diene system within the molecule (the enol double bond in conjunction with the exocyclic isopropenyl alkene).

column1: Step 2 — Intramolecular Diels-Alder reaction: The enol and the isopropenyl group together form the necessary diene-dienophile pair for an intramolecular [4+2] cycloaddition. The reaction proceeds through a well-defined transition state (shown in the answer with numbered carbons 1–7)
column2: where the two reacting π-systems are brought into close proximity within the cyclic framework.

column1: Step 3 — Product formation: After the cycloaddition and subsequent tautomerization back to the keto form
column2: the final product is a fused bicyclic enone — a compact polycyclic structure bearing a carbonyl group.

column1: The transition state geometry is illustrated showing the endo approach
column2: with hydrogens at specific bridgehead positions
column3: and the numbered carbon atoms (1 through 7) indicate how the new C–C bonds are formed during the [4+2] cycloaddition.

column1: Paquette's Synthesis of Fused Bicyclic Compounds
The starting material is a cyclopentanone derivative bearing a pendant vinyl (allyl-type) side chain.
Step 1 — Enolization: At 320°C
column2: the cyclopentanone undergoes thermal enolization to generate the enol tautomer
column3: which provides a diene system (the enol double bond plus the terminal alkene of the side chain).

column1: Step 2 — Intramolecular Diels-Alder reaction: The enol diene undergoes an intramolecular [4+2] cycloaddition with the pendant alkene acting as the dienophile. This forms a bridged bicyclic enol intermediate containing an oxygen bridge.
Step 3 — Rearrangement to final product: The oxygen-bridged intermediate undergoes tautomerization (retro-enolization)
column2: restoring the ketone carbonyl. The final product is a cis-fused bicyclo[3.3.0]octanone — a fused bicyclopentane system containing a ketone group.

column1: This demonstrates how Paquette utilized the thermal enolization/intramolecular Diels-Alder strategy to efficiently construct fused bicyclic ring systems from relatively simple monocyclic precursors. The key insight is that the transient enol form generated at high temperature provides the necessary diene for the intramolecular cycloaddition
column2: which would not be possible from the keto form alone.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;670b2be8daac77037b0e67ba;TRUE;1

column1: ;Specify the type and the process of the transformation of compound I into II and III
column2: knowing that compound II is a non-isolated intermediate.;;;data/images/670b2be8daac77037b0e67ba_3.png;"Analysis of the Transformation of I into II and III

column1: Since products II and III are polycyclic
column2: we should consider a cycloaddition reaction between the conjugated system of the cycloheptatriene and the isolated double bond (activated by the ester group).

column1: The cycloheptatriene derivative contains 4 double bonds (therefore 8 π electrons). This is most likely an [8+2] cycloaddition
column2: which is thermally allowed in a supra-supra fashion according to the Woodward-Hoffmann rules (there are 10 π electrons involved
column3: which is of the form 4q+2 with q = 2). Therefore
column4: 5 curved arrows are needed to describe the formation of the non-isolated intermediate II.

column1: Step 1: Formation of Compound II
Compound I undergoes an intramolecular [8+2] cycloaddition (thermal reaction at 225°C):
The cycloheptatriene portion provides the 8 π-electron component (4 conjugated double bonds).
The isolated double bond (activated by the ester and cyano groups) acts as the 2 π-electron component (dienophile equivalent).
The reaction proceeds intramolecularly and is thermally allowed in a suprafacial-suprafacial manner.
This produces compound II
column2: which is a non-isolated intermediate — meaning it is a strained
column3: transient polycyclic structure that does not accumulate and immediately undergoes further reaction.

column1: Step 2: Transformation of II into III
Product II is strained and stabilizes itself through a second thermal pericyclic reaction.
Analysis of the structure of III reveals that the transformation from II to III involves a [1
column2: 5]-hydrogen migration — a sigmatropic rearrangement that is thermally allowed in a suprafacial manner according to the Woodward-Hoffmann rules.

column1: Specifically:
A hydrogen atom migrates from one carbon to another carbon 5 atoms away (a [1
column2: 5]-shift).

column1: This migration occurs in a suprafacial fashion on the π system
column2: which is consistent with the thermal conditions.

column1: The [1
column2: 5]-sigmatropic shift involves 6 electrons (4q+2 with q = 1)
column3: confirming it is thermally allowed suprafacially.

column1: This hydrogen migration relieves the strain present in the non-isolated intermediate II and produces the final stable polycyclic product III
column2: which bears the cyano (NC) and ethoxy ester (EtO) substituents on the newly formed ring system.

column1: Summary
Step	Transformation	Reaction Type	Conditions
1	I → II	Intramolecular [8+2] cycloaddition	Thermal (225°C)
column2: supra-supra

column1: 2	II → III	[1
column2: 5]-Sigmatropic hydrogen migration	Thermal
column3: suprafacial

column1: The overall process is a elegant tandem pericyclic sequence: first an intramolecular cycloaddition to form a strained polycyclic intermediate
column2: followed by a sigmatropic rearrangement to relieve strain and yield the final stable product. Both steps are thermally allowed by the Woodward-Hoffmann rules.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;670b2be8daac77037b0e67ba;TRUE;2

column1: 670c23a63dac8d8a9563c206;Two photochemically allowed pericyclic reactions occur in this transformation. What kind of pericyclic reactions are involved?;;;data/images/670c23a63dac8d8a9563c206_1.png;[2s+2s]

column1: ;"What will be the process for the following electrocyclic cyclizations?
1) A conjugated diene (butadiene derivative) undergoes electrocyclic ring closure:
Under thermal conditions (Δ) to give a cyclobutene product with one stereochemistry
Under photochemical conditions (hν) to give a cyclobutene product with a different stereochemistry
2) A conjugated triene (hexatriene derivative) undergoes electrocyclic ring closure:
Under thermal conditions (Δ) to give a cyclohexadiene product with one stereochemistry
Under photochemical conditions (hν) to give a cyclohexadiene product with a different stereochemistry
How can you explain
column2: for each cyclization
column3: the difference in configuration of the two resulting products?";;;data/images/670c23a63dac8d8a9563c206_2.png;"1) Cyclization with 4 π electrons (4n system)

column1: This is an electrocyclic cyclization involving 4 π electrons under two different conditions.
Products:
Thermal conditions (Δ): gives cis-3
column2: 4-dimethylcyclobutene

column1: Photochemical conditions (hν): gives trans-3
column2: 4-dimethylcyclobutene

column1: Explanation of the Configuration Difference
To explain the configuration of the two products resulting from this electrocyclic reaction
column2: we must examine the HOMO of the open (acyclic) system.

column1: Under Thermal Conditions — HOMO Analysis
Under thermal conditions
column2: the relevant orbital is the HOMO (ground state) of the butadiene system.

column1: Looking at the HOMO of butadiene (ψ₂)
column2: the terminal p-orbitals have lobes of the same phase on the same face. For bond formation to occur between the two terminal carbons
column3: the orbitals must rotate in the same direction.

column1: The process is conrotatory. The orbitals rotate in the same direction
column2: and the two methyl groups end up on the same side of the ring. This yields the cis isomer (cis-3
column3: 4-dimethylcyclobutene).

column1: Under Photochemical Conditions — HOMO* (SOMO) Analysis
Under photochemical conditions
column2: one electron is promoted to the next orbital
column3: and the relevant orbital becomes the HOMO* (also called SOMO) — which is ψ₃ of the butadiene system.

column1: In the HOMO*
column2: the terminal p-orbitals have lobes of the same phase on opposite faces. For bond formation
column3: the orbitals must rotate in opposite directions.

column1: The process is disrotatory. The orbitals rotate in opposite directions
column2: and the two methyl groups end up on opposite sides of the ring. This yields the trans isomer (trans-3
column3: 4-dimethylcyclobutene).

column1: 2) Cyclization with 6 π electrons (4q+2 system)
This is an electrocyclic cyclization involving 6 π electrons under two different conditions.
Products:
Photochemical conditions (hν): gives trans-5
column2: 6-dimethylcyclohexa-1
column3: 3-diene

column1: Thermal conditions (Δ): gives cis-5
column2: 6-dimethylcyclohexa-1
column3: 3-diene

column1: Examination of the Frontier Orbitals of the Open Compound
Under Photochemical Conditions — HOMO* Analysis
Under photochemical conditions
column2: the relevant orbital is the HOMO* (excited state SOMO) of the hexatriene system.

column1: In the HOMO*
column2: the terminal p-orbital lobes of the same phase are on the same face. For bond formation
column3: the orbitals rotate in the same direction.

column1: The process is conrotatory. The orbitals rotate in the same direction
column2: and the two methyl groups end up on opposite sides of the ring. This yields the trans isomer (trans-5
column3: 6-dimethylcyclohexa-1
column4: 3-diene).

column1: Under Thermal Conditions — HOMO Analysis
Under thermal conditions
column2: the relevant orbital is the HOMO (ground state) of the hexatriene system.

column1: In the HOMO
column2: the terminal p-orbital lobes of the same phase are on opposite faces. For bond formation
column3: the orbitals must rotate in opposite directions.

column1: The process is disrotatory. The orbitals rotate in opposite directions
column2: and the two methyl groups end up on the same side of the ring. This yields the cis isomer (cis-5
column3: 6-dimethylcyclohexa-1
column4: 3-diene).

column1: In this case
column2: the thermal process is disrotatory while the photochemical process is conrotatory — which is the inverse of the previous case with 4 π electrons.

column1: Key Rules to Remember
In electrocyclic reactions:
a) If the HOMO of the open system is symmetric (4q+2 π electrons)
column2: the cyclization (or ring opening) process is disrotatory (thermal) / conrotatory (photochemical).

column1: b) If the HOMO of the open system is antisymmetric (4n π electrons)
column2: the process is conrotatory (thermal) / disrotatory (photochemical).

column1: π Electrons	Thermal	Photochemical
4n (e.g.
column2: 4)	Conrotatory	Disrotatory
6)	Disrotatory	Conrotatory

column1: These rules are a direct consequence of the Woodward-Hoffmann rules for the conservation of orbital symmetry in pericyclic reactions.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;670c23a63dac8d8a9563c206;TRUE;1
;"The synthesis of a ""bird-cage hydrocarbon""
column2: I
column3: was carried out in the following manner:

column1: Step 1: A bicyclic diene (norbornadiene derivative) is heated at 150°C to undergo a thermal rearrangement
column2: giving compound A.

column1: Step 2: Compound A is then reacted (with a chlorinating agent / through a Diels-Alder reaction with a perchlorinated reagent) to give compound B
column2: which is a polychlorinated polycyclic structure bearing six chlorine atoms.

column1: Step 3: Compound B is irradiated with light (hν) to give compound C
column2: which is a cage-like polychlorinated structure also bearing six chlorine atoms in a more compact
column3: cage-type framework.

column1: Step 4: The reduction of C by lithium in the presence of tert-butyl alcohol in anhydrous THF allows a complete dechlorination
column2: yielding a hydrocarbon of formula I
column3: which is the bird-cage hydrocarbon — a colorless
column4: sublimable solid with the molecular formula C₁₂H₁₄.

column1: Explain the different steps of this synthesis (except for the transformation C → I).";;;data/images/670c23a63dac8d8a9563c206_3.png;"Step 1: Dedimerization of Dicyclopentadiene
The starting material is dicyclopentadiene
column2: which is the [4+2] Diels-Alder dimer of cyclopentadiene.

column1: Upon heating (distillation
column2: Δ)
column3: dicyclopentadiene undergoes a retro-Diels-Alder reaction. This is a thermal [4+2] cycloreversion that cleaves the dimer back into two molecules of cyclopentadiene (compound A).

column1: The retro-Diels-Alder proceeds through a concerted mechanism where the two C–C bonds formed during the original dimerization break simultaneously
column2: regenerating two equivalents of the monomeric cyclopentadiene. Cyclopentadiene is the diene that will be used in the next step.

column1: Step 2: [4+2] Cycloaddition (Thermal Diels-Alder Reaction)
Cyclopentadiene (the diene) reacts with hexachloronorbornadiene (the dienophile
column2: also called ""philodiene"") at 120°C in a thermal Diels-Alder [4+2] cycloaddition with a 73% yield.

column1: Cyclopentadiene provides the 4 π-electron diene component.
Hexachloronorbornadiene provides the 2 π-electron dienophile component (activated by the six electron-withdrawing chlorine substituents).
The product is compound B
column2: which is a polychlorinated polycyclic adduct with an endo-endo configuration. The endo selectivity is consistent with the Alder endo rule
column3: where secondary orbital interactions favor the endo transition state. The resulting structure is a norbornane-type framework fused with the chlorinated norbornene unit
column4: bearing six chlorine atoms.

column1: Step 3: Intramolecular [2+2] Cycloaddition (Photochemical)
Compound B is irradiated with UV light (hν)
column2: which triggers an intramolecular [2+2] photocycloaddition with an 85% yield.

column1: The [2+2] cycloaddition is thermally forbidden by the Woodward-Hoffmann rules (it involves 4 π electrons in a suprafacial-suprafacial mode)
column2: but it is photochemically allowed.

column1: Under UV irradiation
column2: one of the double bonds in compound B is excited to its HOMO* (excited state)
column3: allowing the suprafacial-suprafacial [2+2] cycloaddition to proceed.

column1: The two remaining double bonds within the polycyclic framework of B are positioned in close proximity (held rigidly by the cage-like structure)
column2: enabling the intramolecular reaction.

column1: The new C–C bond formed by the [2+2] cycloaddition creates an additional ring
column2: converting the polycyclic structure into the more compact cage compound C. This cage structure still bears the six chlorine atoms but now has the characteristic bird-cage-like framework.

column1: Summary Table
Step	Reaction Type	Conditions	Yield	Product
1	Retro-Diels-Alder (cycloreversion)	Δ (distillation)	—	Cyclopentadiene (A)
2	[4+2] Diels-Alder cycloaddition	120°C
column2: thermal	73%	Endo-endo polychlorinated adduct (B)

column1: 3	Intramolecular [2+2] photocycloaddition	hν (UV light)	85%	Cage compound (C)

The final step (not explained in this answer) involves the complete dechlorination of C using lithium in the presence of tert-butyl alcohol in anhydrous THF to yield the bird-cage hydrocarbon I (C₁₂H₁₄).
Additional Details
Irradiation Conditions
The irradiation (Step 3) is carried out using a low-pressure mercury lamp (Hanovia
Step 4: Dechlorination According to Winstein
C → I using lithium + tert-butanol (tBuOH) in THF
column2: with a yield of 75%.

column1: This is a reductive dechlorination following Winstein's method
column2: where lithium metal acts as the reducing agent and tert-butanol serves as the proton source
column3: in THF as solvent. All six chlorine atoms are removed and replaced by hydrogen atoms
column4: yielding the bird-cage hydrocarbon I (C₁₂H₁₄).

column1: Important Remarks on the Selectivity
Regioselectivity of the [4+2] Cycloaddition

The structure of B implies that the [4+2] Diels-Alder cycloaddition occurred exclusively at the level of the double bond of the dienophile that does not bear chlorine atoms. This double bond is less electron-rich than the other one
column2: on which the chlorines would exert a mesomeric +M (electron-donating) effect. It is well known that a Diels-Alder reaction proceeds more readily when the reacting double bond of the dienophile is more electron-deficient. The best approach to this problem would require the calculation of orbital stabilization energies (see O. Eisenstein et al.
column3: Tetrahedron

column1: Endo-Endo Selectivity
The preferential formation of the endo-endo adduct B is explained by:
Secondary orbital interactions: Attractive secondary orbital interactions occur between the two double bonds in B during the transition state
column2: stabilizing the endo approach.

column1: Steric considerations: The steric hindrance caused by the dichloromethano bridge in the dienophile during the supra-supra approach of the diene also favors the endo-endo configuration.
These two factors combined explain why the endo-endo adduct is the major product of the Diels-Alder reaction.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;670c23a63dac8d8a9563c206;TRUE;2

column2: (R) or (S)
column3: for the four stereocenters moving from left to right in the reaction scheme.;;;data/images/670c2a003aa4e3c3bc4aae8e_1.png;(R)

column1: ;"Part 1
(S)-Naproxen can be synthesized in enantiomerically pure form using a chiral reagent
column3: 1'-bi-2-naphthol (shown opposite).

column1: The structure of bi-2-naphthol consists of two naphthalene rings connected at the 1
column2: 1' positions
column3: each bearing a hydroxyl group (OH) at the 2-position.

column1: Part 2
Due to steric hindrance
column2: the two hydroxyl groups — and therefore the two biphenyl (binaphthyl) rings — cannot be in the same plane. Show that this compound exists as two enantiomers.

column1: Part 3
De";;;data/images/670c2a003aa4e3c3bc4aae8e_2.png;"Explaining the Stereoselectivity of the B → C Transformation
To explain the stereoselectivity of the transformation from B to C
column2: we assume that the mechanism involves an intermediate in which two lithium ions coordinate with (complex) the two negatively charged oxygen atoms of the binaphthol ester.

column1: Description of the Intermediate
The intermediate shown has the following features:
The two oxygen atoms of the binaphthol portion are deprotonated and bear negative charges.
Two lithium cations (Li⁺) coordinate to these oxygen atoms
column2: forming a rigid chelated complex.

column1: The naphthalene ring (labeled ""Napth"") of the substrate is positioned on one side of this rigid chelate.
The α-carbon (carbon between the carbonyl and the naphthalene ring) is labeled as carbon 3 in the structure.
Explanation of the Selectivity
When n-BuLi deprotonates the α-carbon of the ester (adjacent to the carbonyl)
column2: it generates a carbanion (enolate). This enolate is held in a rigid
column3: chelated conformation by the two lithium ions coordinating with the two oxygen atoms.

column1: Due to this rigid chelated structure
column2: one face of the enolate is blocked by the bulky binaphthyl group of the chiral auxiliary. The methyl iodide (CH₃I) can therefore only approach and alkylate the enolate from the less hindered face.

column1: The (R)-binaphthol chiral auxiliary controls which face is accessible
column2: directing the methylation to occur preferentially from one side. This results in the preferential formation of one enantiomer over the other at the α-carbon
column3: ultimately leading to the (S)-configuration in the final naproxen product after hydrolysis.

column1: Titration of a Commercial Tablet Containing Racemic Naproxen
Experimental Procedure
A commercial tablet containing racemic naproxen is assayed as follows:
The tablet is ground in a mortar.
The resulting powder is dissolved in 100 mL of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) solution at a concentration of 0.097 M (the solvent is a water/ethanol mixture).
The solution is filtered
column2: the filter is rinsed
column3: and then the filtrate is titrated with 0.1 M hydrochloric acid (HCl).

column1: Interpretation of the Titration Curve
The titration curve shows pH vs. volume of acid added (V_acid in mL)
column2: along with the first derivative curve (dpH/dV).

column1: The curve displays two equivalence points:
First equivalence point: at V₁ = 9.68 mL
This corresponds to the neutralization of the excess NaOH (the sodium hydroxide that did not react with naproxen). At this point
column2: the HCl is neutralizing the free NaOH:

column1: NaOH + HCl → NaCl + H₂O
Second equivalence point: at V₂ = 19.45 mL
This corresponds to the neutralization of the sodium naproxenate (the sodium salt of naproxen formed when naproxen reacted with NaOH). At this point
column2: the HCl is converting the sodium naproxenate back to free naproxen (the carboxylic acid form):

column1: Naproxen-Na⁺ + HCl → Naproxen-H + NaCl
Quantitative Analysis
The volume of HCl used to neutralize the excess NaOH = V₁ = 9.68 mL
The volume of HCl used to neutralize the sodium naproxenate = V₂ - V₁ = 19.45 - 9.68 = 9.77 mL
Moles of naproxen in the tablet = C(HCl) × (V₂ - V₁) = 0.1 × 9.77 × 10⁻³ = 9.77 × 10⁻⁴ mol
Molar mass of naproxen (C₁₄H₁₄O₃) = 230 g/mol
Mass of naproxen = 9.77 × 10⁻⁴ × 230 = 0.225 g ≈ 225 mg
This is consistent with a typical commercial naproxen tablet dosage.
The initial amount of NaOH = 0.097 × 100 × 10⁻³ = 9.7 × 10⁻³ mol
column2: which is in excess compared to the amount of naproxen
column3: confirming that all the naproxen was converted to its sodium salt before titration.

column1: Naproxen — Asymmetry of Bi-naphthol
Due to steric hindrance
column2: there is no free rotation around the C–C bond connecting the two naphthalene bicycles. The two rings are in nearly perpendicular planes. This restricted rotation is the cause of the asymmetry. Let us verify the existence of enantiomers.

column1: Proving the Existence of Two Enantiomers
If we draw the mirror image of compound I
column2: we obtain compound II
column3: which is not superimposable on I. If we perform a 180° rotation around an axis perpendicular to the C–C bond
column4: we observe that the OH group moves to the back of the plane (form III). The steric hindrance prevents this group from passing to the front of the plane. We can superimpose the two rings contained in the plane (for stereoisomers I and III)
column5: but it is impossible for the perpendicular rings. Therefore
column6: we have two enantiomers.

column1: Determining (R) or (S) Configuration
The (R) or (S) character is determined by ranking the groups on each side of the carbon in decreasing order of priority
column2: assigning numbers 1 and 2 to one end and numbers 3 and 4 to the other end. We place 3 and 4 at the back of the plane and look at the direction of rotation to go from 1 to 2 then 3. If we turn to the right
column3: the compound is (R). For example
column4: compound I is (R) and compound II is (S).

column1: Asymmetric Synthesis of Naproxen
The synthesis begins with the preparation of the acid chloride A using thionyl chloride (SOCl₂).
Step A → B: Esterification of Bi-naphthol

The acid chloride reacts with bi-naphthol to give a monoester. The second esterification does not occur due to steric hindrance — the bulky environment around the second hydroxyl group prevents a second acylation.
Step B → C: Deprotonation and Methylation
The passage from B to C involves:
Acid-base reaction: n-BuLi first causes deprotonation of the phenol (remaining free OH).
Deprotonation at the α-carbon: n-BuLi then deprotonates the carbon α to the ester
column2: forming a carbanion. This carbanion is more nucleophilic than the phenolate and is stabilized by resonance. It is also less sterically hindered than the phenolate.

column1: SN₂ on methyl iodide: The carbanion performs an SN₂ reaction on CH₃I
column2: resulting in methylation at the α-position of the aromatic ring.

column1: Stereoselectivity of the Methylation

This methylation occurs in a stereoselective manner because the structure of the dianion is asymmetric. The complex formed from the enolate presents a double bond in which one face is blocked by the hydrogen atom carried on carbon 3.
The electron pair of the double bond can only attack the electrophile on the most accessible face (the front face). Therefore
column2: one enantiomer is preferentially formed.

column1: The chelated intermediate (with two lithium ions coordinating the two negatively charged oxygen atoms
column2: as described previously) creates a rigid structure where the back face is encumbered by the naphthalene group (Napth) and the hydrogen at carbon 3
column3: while the front face is open for electrophilic attack by CH₃I. This leads to the preferential formation of the (S)-configuration at the methylated carbon.

column1: Step C → (S)-Naproxen: Saponification and Acidification
The passage from C to naproxen involves:
LiOH: Saponification (base hydrolysis) of the ester
column2: which cleaves the chiral auxiliary (bi-naphthol) and converts the ester back to the carboxylate salt.

column1: HCl: Acidification to convert the carboxylate to the free carboxylic acid.
This last reaction is a saponification followed by acidification
column2: which allows the return to the acid function. It does not affect the asymmetric carbon
column3: and therefore we obtain (S)-naproxen.

column1: As in many stereoselective reactions
column2: an asymmetric reagent is needed to induce asymmetry in the reaction.

column1: Acid-Base Titration — Interpretation
Titration Setup
We are titrating the naproxen back. Before the titration
column2: the major acid-base species present in the sodium hydroxide solution are the excess hydroxide ions and the carboxylate ions (naproxenate). The two successive titration reactions are given below.

column1: First Equivalence Point
In the first jump
column2: we titrate:

column1: RP1: OH⁻ + H₃O⁺ → 2 H₂O
column2: K₁ = 10¹⁴

column1: The volume at the first equivalence point is 0.1 × 9.68 × 10⁻³ = 9.68 × 10⁻⁴ mol of OH⁻
column2: which is the initial quantity of OH⁻ ions introduced. The naproxen is therefore present in the tablet in the form of a salt (sodium naproxenate
column3: i.e.
column4: sodium salt form).

column1: Second Equivalence Point

RP2: RCOO⁻ + H₃O⁺ → RCOOH
column2: K₂ = 1/Kₐ

column1: We therefore have in the tablet: (19.45 − 9.68) × 10⁻³ × 0.1 = 0.98 × 10⁻³ mol (± 0.01 × 10⁻³)
column2: which gives a mass of 247 mg (± 3).

column1: pKₐ Determination
The pKₐ is read on the curve at the half-equivalence point of the second titration. A value close to 5.2 is found
column2: which is higher than that of benzoic acid. This can be explained by the better stabilization of the conjugate base:

column1: The −I (electron-withdrawing) effect of the phenyl group is expressed through two bonds.
The methyl group reinforces the charge through its +I (electron-donating) effect.
This makes the naproxenate anion more stable than the benzoate anion

The resonance structure shows the delocalization of the negative charge across the aromatic system with stabilization by the methoxy group.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;670c2a003aa4e3c3bc4aae8e;TRUE;1

column1: ;"Aspartame (M.W. = 200) was discovered in 1969 by J. Schlatter at the Searle & Co. company during the synthesis of a tetrapeptide. column1: Questions

column1: A possible synthesis that allows the conservation of the stereochemistry (S) of the asymmetric centers of the starting compounds is given below
column2: starting from aspartic acid.

column1: Step 1: Addition-Elimination

F is treated with PBr₃ in ethyl acetate to give a cyclic intermediate (an oxazoline-type ring system containing nitrogen and sulfur
column2: fused to the aspartate backbone).

column1: Step 3: Hydrolysis and Amine Deprotection
The cyclic intermediate is treated with:
C₆H₅ group
H₂O
Along with C₆H₅ and an amino acid derivative to give compound G

column3: a carboxylic acid (HOOC)
column4: and an ester (CO₂CH₃).

column1: Step 4: Peptide Coupling (Final Step)
The last step is the peptide coupling.
Explain why the reaction medium must be slightly basic.
What are the best electrophilic and nucleophilic sites in the two compounds?
Give the preferential attack.
When the mixture is acidified at the end of the reaction
column2: a gas is released — what is it?

column1: Explain the pH value of 4.5 at which one must work to obtain aspartame.
Conditions: 2) HCl
column2: pH = 4.5";;;data/images/670c2a003aa4e3c3bc4aae8e_3.png;"Aspartame — Peptide Bond

column1: A peptide bond is an amide bond. It is the bond formed between the carboxyl group of one amino acid and the amino group of another amino acid
column2: with the loss of water.

column1: Asymmetric Carbons
There are two asymmetric carbons in aspartame
column2: bearing different substituents. This gives rise to 4 possible stereoisomers: (R
column3: R); (S
column4: S); (S
column5: R) and (R
column6: S). The (S
column7: S) stereoisomer is the one shown in the Cram projection provided.

column1: In the Cram projection of the (S
column2: S) stereoisomer:

column1: Carbon 1 (from the phenylalanine part): bears H₃COOC (methyl ester)
column2: the NH-CO (amide bond)
column3: C₆H₅CH₂ (benzyl group)
column4: and H

column1: Carbon 3 (from the aspartic acid part): bears NH₂
column2: CH₂COOH
column3: COOH
column4: and H

column1: Both centers have the (S) absolute configuration.
Predominance Diagram
Amino acids contain both a carboxylic acid function and an amine function. In aqueous solution
column2: they exist as zwitterions through intramolecular acid-base reaction — meaning the hydrogen atom from the carboxylic acid transfers to the amine function.

column1: At acidic pH
column2: all basic functions are protonated. The lowest pKₐ (1.8) corresponds to the deprotonation of the carboxylic acid function of the amino acid. Indeed
column3: the inductive electron-withdrawing (−I) effect of the NH₃⁺ group delocalizes the negative charge
column4: making this carboxylic acid function more acidic.

column1: In the case of aspartic acid
column2: the second pKₐ of 3.8 is associated with the second carboxylic acid function
column3: whose conjugate base does not benefit from this stabilization.

column1: Finally
column2: above pH = 9.6
column3: the ammonium group is deprotonated.

column1: Predominance Diagram:
pH range	Major species
pH < 1.8	AH₃⁺ — Fully protonated: HOOC–CH(NH₃⁺)–CH₂–COOH
1.8 < pH < 3.8	AH₂ — First COOH deprotonated: ⁻OOC–CH(NH₃⁺)–CH₂–COOH
3.8 < pH < 9.6	AH⁻ — Both COOH groups deprotonated: ⁻OOC–CH(NH₃⁺)–CH₂–COO⁻ (zwitterion)
pH > 9.6	A²⁻ — Fully deprotonated: ⁻OOC–CH(NH₂)–CH₂–COO⁻
Obtaining Compound F: Addition-Elimination (AdEl) Mechanism
Two possible leaving groups exist: CH₃S⁻ and CH₃CH₂O⁻.
The C–S bond is less energetic (weaker) than the C–O bond. Therefore
column2: CH₃S⁻ is a better leaving group than CH₃CH₂O⁻.

column1: Mechanism:
The amine (NH₂) of aspartic acid acts as the nucleophile.
It attacks the electrophilic carbon of the dithiocarbonate (C=S).
This forms a tetrahedral intermediate (addition step).
The CH₃S⁻ group departs as the leaving group (elimination step)
column2: since the C–S bond is weaker.

column1: This yields compound F
column2: where the amine is now protected by the ethoxythiocarbonyl group
column3: with release of HSCH₃ (methanethiol).

column1: Passage from F to G: Cyclization with PBr₃
Mechanism:
PBr₃ reacts with the carboxylic acid group of compound F
column2: forming an acyl bromide (acid bromide). This activates the carbonyl toward cyclization.

column1: The sulfur atom of the thiocarbonyl group acts as an intramolecular nucleophile and attacks the newly formed acyl bromide carbon
column2: leading to cyclization.

column1: The oxonium ion (or thionium ion) obtained is then attacked by a bromide ion.
This produces a cyclic intermediate — an N
column2: S-containing heterocyclic ring (thiazolidine-type or oxazoline-type ring) fused to the aspartate backbone.

column1: Obtaining Aspartame: Peptide Coupling (Final Step)
Why slightly basic medium?
The reaction is performed in slightly basic medium to avoid the acid-base reaction between the amine and the carboxylate functions. At pH ≈ 9
column2: the acid is in its carboxylate form (deprotonated)
column3: which prevents unwanted proton transfer.

column1: Best electrophilic and nucleophilic sites:

The best electrophilic site is the carbonyl carbon bonded to sulfur (the thioester carbonyl). The carbonyl bonded to the amide is less electrophilic due to the mesomeric (+M) donation from the nitrogen into the carbonyl.
The best nucleophilic site is the amine group (NH₂) of the phenylalanine methyl ester component.
Preferential attack:
The amine attacks the thioester carbonyl (C=O bonded to S)
column2: which is the most electrophilic carbon. This is an addition-elimination at the thioester
column3: forming the new peptide (amide) bond.

column1: Gas released upon acidification:
Upon acidification
column2: a good leaving group departs
column3: releasing COS (carbonyl sulfide)
column4: which is a gaseous molecule of similar structure to CO₂. This release of COS is what regenerates the free amine (removes the protecting group).

column1: Why pH = 4.5?
The pH is set to 4.5 because at this value
column2: we are in the predominance domain of the zwitterion (the pKₐ of 1.8 for the carboxylic acid acidity no longer exists — meaning the carboxylate is protonated back to the acid and the amine remains as NH₃⁺). At pH 4.5
column3: aspartame exists in its zwitterionic form
column4: which is the desired final product. This pH ensures proper protonation states for the final aspartame molecule.

column1: Final Reaction Summary:
The phenylalanine methyl ester derivative attacks the activated (thioester) carbonyl of the aspartic acid derivative. After formation of the peptide bond
column2: acidification to pH 4.5 releases COS gas and yields aspartame in its zwitterionic form.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;670c2a003aa4e3c3bc4aae8e;TRUE;2

column1: ;Complete this reaction;;;data/images/6711410d39fb87be5f2f165d_2.png;"This is the Schmidt Reaction
Starting Material
The starting material is a cyclopentanone bearing a pendant azide chain (an alkyl chain with a terminal azido group
column2: –N₃) at the α-position of the ketone.

column1: Reagent
The reaction is carried out using trifluoroacetic acid (CF₃CO₂H) as the acid catalyst.
Reaction Description
The Schmidt reaction is an acid-catalyzed reaction between a ketone (or carboxylic acid/aldehyde) and an azide (–N₃). In this case
column2: the reaction is intramolecular since the azide group is tethered to the ketone on the same molecule.

column1: Mechanism Overview
Acid activation: Trifluoroacetic acid protonates the carbonyl oxygen of the cyclopentanone
column2: making the carbonyl carbon more electrophilic.

column1: Nucleophilic attack: The terminal nitrogen of the azide group attacks the activated carbonyl carbon intramolecularly.
Loss of N₂: After the azide nitrogen adds to the carbonyl
column2: molecular nitrogen (N₂) is lost as a leaving group.
2-Migration: An alkyl group migrates from the carbon adjacent to the carbonyl to the electron-deficient nitrogen (similar to a Beckmann-type rearrangement)
column3: resulting in ring expansion.

column1: Tautomerization: The intermediate rearranges to give the final stable product.
Product

The product is a bicyclic lactam — specifically a fused bicyclic system containing a nitrogen atom incorporated into the ring. The original five-membered cyclopentanone ring has been expanded to a six-membered ring through the insertion of the nitrogen atom
column2: and the pendant chain has cyclized to form the second fused ring
column3: yielding an indolizidinone-type structure (a fused 5-6 bicyclic ring system containing a nitrogen atom and a carbonyl group).

column1: This intramolecular Schmidt reaction is a powerful method for constructing nitrogen-containing bicyclic frameworks commonly found in natural products and alkaloids.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;6711410d39fb87be5f2f165d;TRUE;1

;What is the product obtained during the intramolecular cyclization in the presence of TFA (trifluoroacetic acid)?;;;data/images/6711410d39fb87be5f2f165d_3.png;"Product of the Intramolecular Cyclization with TFA
Starting Material
The starting material is a cyclopentanone derivative bearing:
A tert-butyl group (t-Bu) on the cyclopentanone ring
A pendant alkyl chain terminated by an azido group (–N₃)
Reagent
Trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) acts as the acid catalyst to promote the intramolecular cyclization.
Product
The product obtained is a bicyclic lactam (a cyclic amide) consisting of:
A seven-membered ring (azepanone) containing the nitrogen atom and the carbonyl group
A fused five-membered ring (pyrrolidine-type) formed by the cyclization of the pendant chain
The tert-butyl group (t-Bu) is retained on the larger ring
A hydrogen atom is present at the ring junction
Explanation
This is an intramolecular Schmidt reaction:
TFA protonates the carbonyl oxygen of the cyclopentanone
column2: activating it toward nucleophilic attack.

column1: The azide nitrogen attacks the electrophilic carbonyl carbon intramolecularly.
Molecular nitrogen (N₂) is expelled as a leaving group.
A 1
column2: 2-alkyl migration occurs
column3: resulting in a ring expansion of the original five-membered ketone to a seven-membered lactam.

column1: Simultaneously
column2: the chain cyclizes to form the fused bicyclic system.

column1: The overall transformation converts a monocyclic azido-ketone into a fused bicyclic nitrogen-containing ring system through ring expansion and cyclization
column2: which is characteristic of the intramolecular Schmidt reaction promoted by a strong acid such as TFA.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;6711410d39fb87be5f2f165d;TRUE;2

column1: ;"Nucleic acids are polymers in which phosphate groups are bonded to deoxyriboses (2-deoxyriboses) that carry four bases: cytosine
column2: thymine
column3: adenine
column4: and guanine.

column1: [Structures of adenine
column2: cytosine
column3: guanine
column4: and thymine are shown]

column1: Write the different tautomeric forms of the four bases.";;;data/images/67114acc95aeb4d1c92426a5_2.png;"Solution: Tautomeric Forms
Explanation
For each of the four bases
column2: one can write a certain number of tautomeric forms. In the case of the last three bases (cytosine
column3: guanine
column4: and thymine)
column5: which contain at least one amide functional group
column6: one can write a tautomeric form that makes the aromatic character of the six-membered ring appear.

column1: It is important to note that these tautomeric forms involve an iminol
column2: which is very unstable. This is because the energy of the C=O double bond is much greater than that of the C=N bond. Therefore
column3: even though one recovers some resonance energy (by gaining aromaticity in the ring)
column4: this is lost due to the disappearance of the amide motif.

column1: In other words
column2: the amide (keto) forms are the dominant/stable tautomers
column3: and the iminol (enol) forms
column4: while they can be drawn
column5: are much less stable.

column1: Tautomeric Forms of Each Base
Adenine
Form 1 (amino form
column2: dominant): The NH2 group is attached to the purine ring as an amine. The ring nitrogens carry their usual lone pairs and one N-H bond.

column1: Form 2 (imino form): A proton shifts from the NH2 group to an adjacent ring nitrogen
column2: converting the -NH2 into =NH (imino)
column3: while the ring nitrogen becomes N-H. This is the less stable tautomer.

column1: Cytosine
Form 1 (keto/amino form
column2: dominant): The C=O (carbonyl) group is intact
column3: and the NH2 group is present as an amine. The ring is non-aromatic in the conventional sense.

column1: Form 2 (enol/amino form): The carbonyl oxygen picks up a proton to become -OH (enol/iminol)
column2: and the adjacent nitrogen loses a proton. This allows the six-membered ring to become fully aromatic. However
column3: this form is less stable because the loss of the strong C=O bond is not sufficiently compensated by the gain in aromaticity.

column1: Thymine
Form 1 (diketo form
column2: dominant): Both C=O groups are intact as carbonyls
column3: with N-H bonds on the ring nitrogens.

column1: Form 2 (enol form): One (or both) of the carbonyl oxygens picks up a proton to become -OH
column2: and the corresponding ring nitrogen loses its proton. This generates greater aromaticity in the six-membered ring
column3: but the tautomer is less stable due to the loss of the strong C=O bond(s) and the amide stabilization.

column1: Guanine (not shown in the solution image but follows the same logic)
Keto/amino form (dominant): The C=O group is intact
column2: and the NH2 group is present.

column1: Enol/imino form: The carbonyl converts to an enol (-OH)
column2: and/or the amine converts to an imine (=NH)
column3: allowing aromaticity in the six-membered ring. Again
column4: this is the less stable tautomer.

column1: Key Takeaway
The keto (amide) tautomers are strongly favored over the enol (iminol) tautomers for cytosine
column2: thymine
column3: and guanine because the C=O double bond energy is significantly higher than that of C=N. Although the enol forms gain aromatic stabilization in the ring
column4: this does not compensate for the loss of the amide functional group. For adenine
column5: the amino form is similarly favored over the imino form.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;67114acc95aeb4d1c92426a5;TRUE;1

column1: ;Rank the following molecules in order of increasing basicity (increasing pKa).;;;data/images/67114acc95aeb4d1c92426a5_3.png;"Answer: Ranking Molecules in Order of Increasing Basicity (Increasing pKa)
Part 1
The molecules given are:
Cyclohexanoxide ion (cyclohexyl-O⁻)
4-Nitrophenylthiolate ion (O₂N-C₆H₄-S⁻)
2-Nitrophenylthiolate ion (O₂N-C₆H₄-S⁻
column2: with NO₂ ortho)

column1: Phenoxide ion (C₆H₅-O⁻)
Analysis of each base:
Cyclohexanoxide (cyclohexyl-O⁻):
This is a strong base because of the electron-donating inductive effect of the cyclohexyl group (alkyl group).
There is no resonance stabilization of the negative charge since the oxygen is attached to a saturated (non-aromatic) ring.
The negative charge is localized on oxygen
column2: making the conjugate base unstable
column3: and therefore the species is a strong base (highest pKa).

column1: Phenoxide (C₆H₅-O⁻):
The negative charge on oxygen is stabilized by resonance with the aromatic ring. The lone pair on O⁻ can be delocalized into the ring
column2: giving rise to several resonance structures (charge spread onto the ortho and para carbons).

column1: Because the base is stabilized by resonance
column2: it is a weaker base than cyclohexanoxide.

column1: 4-Nitrophenylthiolate (O₂N-C₆H₄-S⁻
column2: para):

column1: Sulfur is less basic than oxygen because sulfur is a larger atom (size S > O). The negative charge is more stable on larger atoms because it is more diffuse
column2: making the conjugate base more stable and therefore less basic (weaker base).

column1: Additionally
column2: the base is stabilized by resonance. Here
column3: there are five resonance forms
column4: including one additional resonance structure involving the -NO₂ group. The base is more stable
column5: and therefore less strong (weaker base).

column1: 2-Nitro-3
column2: 5-dimethylphenylthiolate (with NO₂ ortho and two CH₃ groups):

column1: Here
column2: the resonance structure involving the NO₂ group is hindered by steric effects. The two CH₃ groups flanking the NO₂ group force it out of the plane of the ring
column3: preventing effective conjugation/resonance.

column1: Because the resonance stabilization is disrupted
column2: the base here is less stable
column3: and therefore more basic (stronger base) compared to the 4-nitrophenylthiolate.

column1: Final Ranking (Increasing Basicity / Increasing pKa):
4-Nitrophenylthiolate < 2-Nitro-3
column2: 5-dimethylphenylthiolate < Phenoxide < Cyclohexanoxide

column1: (Least basic → Most basic)
Part 2
The molecules given are:
Pyrrole (five-membered aromatic ring with NH)
Pyridine (six-membered aromatic ring with N)
Analysis:
Pyrrole:
In pyrrole
column2: the lone pair on nitrogen participates in the aromatic resonance of the ring. This lone pair is part of the aromatic π-system (contributing 2 electrons to the 6 π-electron aromatic system).

column1: This leads to five resonance structures (mesomeric forms) for pyrrole
column2: in which the lone pair is extensively delocalized.

column1: Because the lone pair is engaged in maintaining aromaticity
column2: it is not readily available for protonation. If pyrrole were to accept a proton
column3: it would lose its aromaticity
column4: which is very energetically unfavorable.

column1: Therefore
column2: the conjugate base (pyrrole itself) is very stable
column3: making pyrrole a very weak base (much weaker than pyridine).

column1: Pyridine:
In pyridine
column2: the nitrogen lone pair is in an sp² hybrid orbital that lies in the plane of the ring
column3: perpendicular to the π-system. This lone pair does not participate in the aromatic π-system.

column1: Therefore
column2: the lone pair is freely available for protonation without disrupting the aromaticity of the ring.

column1: Pyridine is a much stronger base than pyrrole.
Final Ranking (Increasing Basicity / Increasing pKa):
Pyrrole < Pyridine
(Pyrrole is the weaker base; pyridine is the stronger base)";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;67114acc95aeb4d1c92426a5;TRUE;2

A tertiary alcohol cannot be oxidized to a carbonyl

column1: ;Complete this reaction;;;data/images/6712d9d097b88a1cdb76c51e5_2.png;"Oxidation of an Allylic Alcohol Using PCC
The Reaction
Starting material: A tertiary allylic alcohol — specifically
column4: 6-trimethyl-2-cyclohexen-1-ol (a cyclohexene ring bearing an OH group at an allylic position
column5: with three methyl substituents).

column1: Reagent: PCC (Pyridinium Chlorochromate) in DCM (Dichloromethane
column2: CH₂Cl₂) as the solvent.

column1: Product: An α
column2: β-unsaturated carbonyl compound (an enone) — specifically
column5: 6-trimethyl-2-cyclohexen-1-one. The OH group has been oxidized to a C=O (ketone)
column6: and the double bond has shifted position (1

column1: The Reagent: PCC (Pyridinium Chlorochromate)
PCC has the structure:
It consists of a chromium(VI) center bonded to oxygen atoms and a chloride (O=Cr(-Cl)(=O)(O⁻)).
This chromate anion is paired with a pyridinium cation (protonated pyridine
column2: C₅H₅NH⁺).

column1: PCC is a mild oxidizing agent commonly used in organic chemistry. It is particularly useful because:
It can oxidize primary alcohols to aldehydes without further oxidation to carboxylic acids.
It can oxidize secondary alcohols to ketones.
It works well in anhydrous conditions (in DCM)
column2: which prevents over-oxidation.

column1: The Babler-Dauben Oxidation
This specific reaction is an example of the Babler-Dauben oxidation
column2: which is defined as:

column1: A catalytic chromium-mediated 1
column2: 3-oxidative transposition of allylic alcohols to give α
column3: β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds.

column1: What does this mean?
Allylic alcohol: An alcohol where the OH group is on a carbon adjacent to (allylic to) a C=C double bond.

column2: 3-oxidative transposition: During the oxidation
column3: the functional group transformation is accompanied by a shift (transposition) of the double bond. Specifically
column4: the C=C double bond moves by one position (a 1
column5: 3-shift)
column6: and simultaneously the OH is oxidized to a C=O.

column1: α
column2: β-unsaturated carbonyl: The product has a C=C double bond conjugated with the newly formed C=O group (i.e.
column3: the double bond is between the α and β carbons relative to the carbonyl).

column1: How it works conceptually:
The allylic alcohol has the arrangement: C=C-C(OH)
After oxidative transposition
column2: the product has: C(=O)-C=C

column1: The double bond has effectively ""moved"" from one side of the carbon bearing the OH to the other side
column2: while the OH became a carbonyl.

column1: Typical reagent systems for this reaction:
Jones reagent (CrO₃ in aqueous H₂SO₄)
PDC (Pyridinium Dichromate)
PCC (Pyridinium Chlorochromate)
All of these are chromium(VI)-based oxidants that can mediate this type of allylic oxidative transposition.
Reaction Mechanism of the Babler-Dauben Oxidation
Overview of the Reaction
As described previously
column2: the starting material is a cyclic tertiary allylic alcohol (2
column4: 6-trimethyl-2-cyclohexen-1-ol)
column5: which is treated with PCC (Pyridinium Chlorochromate) in DCM (Dichloromethane) to give an α
column6: β-unsaturated ketone (an enone) via a 1

column1: Suggested Mechanism
A suggested mechanism of the Babler-Dauben oxidation proceeds in two key steps:
Step 1: Formation of the Chromate Ester
The cyclic tertiary allylic alcohol reacts with (adds to) pyridinium chlorochromate (PCC) to form the corresponding chromate ester.
In this step
column2: the OH group of the allylic alcohol attacks the chromium center
column3: displacing the chloride ion. This forms a Cr-O bond between the alcohol oxygen and the chromium(VI)
column4: creating a chromate ester intermediate.

column1: Essentially: R-OH + PCC → R-O-Cr(=O)₂-Cl (chromate ester)
Step 2: 1
column2: 3-Oxidative Transposition

column1: The chromate ester intermediate then undergoes a 1
column2: 3-oxidative transposition
column3: which affords the 3-alkyl α
column4: β-unsaturated ketone as the product.

column1: There are two possible pathways suggested for this transposition step:
Pathway A (Ionization pathway):
The allylic alcohol is ionized
column2: meaning the C-O bond breaks heterolytically to generate an allylic carbocation (stabilized by resonance with the adjacent double bond).

column1: This carbocation then recombines with the chromate at a different position (the carbon that was originally part of the double bond).
Subsequent elimination from this new chromate ester gives the transposed enone product.
Pathway B (Concerted or sigmatropic-like rearrangement):

The chromate ester undergoes a concerted rearrangement where the bond reorganization (shift of the double bond and oxidation of the alcohol to a carbonyl) happens simultaneously through a cyclic transition state.
Summary of the Mechanism
Allylic alcohol + PCC → Chromate ester (the OH group adds to chromium
column2: displacing chloride)

column1: Chromate ester → α
column2: β-unsaturated ketone via 1
column3: 3-oxidative transposition
column4: either through:

column1: An ionization pathway (formation of an allylic carbocation followed by recombination with chromate)
column2: or

column1: A concerted rearrangement
The net result is that the OH is oxidized to a C=O
column2: and the C=C double bond migrates by one position to become conjugated with the new carbonyl
column3: giving the α
column4: β-unsaturated ketone product.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;6712d9d097b88a1cdb76c51e;TRUE;1

column1: Key Issue: Difficulty with Secondary Allylic Alcohols
The Babler-Dauben oxidation of secondary allylic alcohols proves to be more difficult to control than that of tertiary analogues. While tertiary allylic alcohols give clean 1
column2: 3-oxidative transposition products
column3: secondary allylic alcohols produce a mixture of products — the desired product along with a high proportion of side-products.

column1: The Reaction
Starting material: A secondary allylic alcohol of the general structure:
Ar-CH=CH-CH(OH)-R (an allylic alcohol where the carbon bearing the OH also bears a hydrogen
column2: making it secondary
column3: with an aryl group Ar on one end and an alkyl group R on the other)

column1: Reagents: H₅IO₆ (periodic acid)
column2: 5% PCC (pyridinium chlorochromate)
column3: in MeCN (acetonitrile) at room temperature.

column1: Products Obtained
Three products are formed:
Product (a) — Desired Product
Ar-C(=O)-CH=CH-R
This is the α
column2: β-unsaturated ketone resulting from the expected 1
column3: 3-oxidative transposition.

column1: The OH has been oxidized to a carbonyl (C=O) on the carbon adjacent to the aryl group
column2: and the C=C double bond has shifted to become conjugated with the new carbonyl.

column1: This is the desired product of the Babler-Dauben oxidation.
Product (b) — Side Product
Ar-C(=O)-CH₂-CH₂-R (or a saturated ketone)
This is a side product where the double bond may have been lost (over-reduction or migration leading to a saturated carbonyl compound)
column2: or alternatively a different regiochemical outcome of the oxidation.

column1: Product (c) — Side Product
R-CH=CH-C(=O)-Ar or another isomeric enone
column2: possibly with the double bond and carbonyl in a different arrangement
column3: or an aldehyde product.

column1: Specifically
column2: from the image
column3: product (c) appears to be: R-C(=O)-H or Ar-CH=CH-CHO
column4: meaning direct oxidation of the secondary alcohol to an aldehyde or ketone without the 1
column5: 3-transposition occurring.

column1: Why This Happens
The difficulty arises because:
Secondary carbocations are less stable than tertiary carbocations. In the ionization pathway of the mechanism
column2: the allylic carbocation intermediate formed from a secondary alcohol is less stabilized
column3: making the 1
column4: 3-transposition less favorable and less selective.

column1: Competing direct oxidation: Instead of undergoing the desired 1
column2: 3-oxidative transposition
column3: the secondary allylic alcohol can simply be oxidized in place (direct oxidation of the C-OH to C=O without any double bond migration)
column4: giving a non-transposed product.

column1: Other side reactions such as double bond migration
column2: over-oxidation
column3: or elimination can also occur
column4: leading to the mixture of products (a)
column6: and (c).

column1: Summary
Unlike tertiary allylic alcohols
column2: which undergo clean Babler-Dauben oxidation to give α
column3: β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds
column4: secondary allylic alcohols give a mixture of the desired transposed enone (a) along with side products (b) and (c). This makes the reaction more difficult to control and less synthetically useful for secondary substrates.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;6712d9d097b88a1cdb76c51e;TRUE;2

column1: Analysis of the ¹H NMR Spectrum
Multiplicity	Chemical Shift (δ ppm)	Number of H	Attribution
Doublet	0.92	6	2 equivalent CH₃ groups adjacent to a CH (isopropyl group)
Multiplet	1.75	1	CH adjacent to several H atoms (isopropyl group — the methine proton)
Singlet	2.07	1	OH (labile proton — confirmed by disappearance upon D₂O addition)

Detailed Interpretation
Peak at 0.92 ppm (Doublet
The integration of 6H and the doublet pattern indicate two equivalent methyl groups (CH₃) that are each split by one adjacent CH proton.
This is characteristic of an isopropyl group: (CH₃)₂CH-
The two CH₃ groups are equivalent because they are both attached to the same CH carbon.
Peak at 1.75 ppm (Multiplet
This 1H multiplet corresponds to the methine (CH) proton of the isopropyl group.
It appears as a multiplet because it is adjacent to multiple hydrogen atoms — specifically the 6 protons of the two CH₃ groups on one side and the 2 protons of the CH₂ group on the other side.
Peak at 2.07 ppm (Singlet
This 1H singlet corresponds to the OH proton of the alcohol.
This is confirmed by the fact that it disappears upon addition of D₂O (the OH proton exchanges with deuterium: O-H → O-D
column2: and the signal vanishes).

column1: OH protons typically appear as singlets because rapid exchange averages out any coupling.
Peak at 3.39 ppm (Doublet
This 2H doublet corresponds to a CH₂ group that is adjacent to one CH proton (hence the doublet splitting).
The relatively downfield chemical shift (3.39 ppm) indicates that this CH₂ is attached to an electron-withdrawing atom
column2: which is the oxygen of the alcohol (-CH₂-OH).

column1: Structure of B
Putting all the pieces together:
Isopropyl group: (CH₃)₂CH-
CH₂ group next to oxygen: -CH₂-OH

CH₃ — CH — CH₂ — OH

column2: 6H at 0.92 ppm) ✓

column2: 1H at 1.75 ppm) ✓

column1: From B to C: Double Esterification and Amidification
Passage from B to C: This involves a double esterification and amidification using acetyl chloride (CH₃COCl) in the presence of pyridine.
What happens:
The two hydroxyl groups (-OH) of compound B (one on the main chain and one on the CH₂OH) are acetylated (converted to acetate esters: -OCOCH₃).
The amine group (-NH₂) is also acylated (converted to an amide: -NHCOCH₃).
Important notes:
These two reactions (esterification and amidification) do not involve the asymmetric carbons and do not change the order of priority of the substituents around them.
Therefore
column2: the absolute configuration of the asymmetric carbons remains unchanged after the reaction.

column1: The reason we protect the amine at this stage is that the next reaction (nitration) uses a sulfonitric mixture (HNO₃/H₂SO₄)
column2: which would oxidize the free amine if left unprotected. Converting it to an amide protects it from oxidation.

Why Not Use an Acid Chloride?
We do not want to esterify the alcohol functions (we want to acylate only the amine).
It is therefore preferable not to use an acid chloride (even though acid chlorides react preferentially with the most reactive/nucleophilic function
column2: which is the amine).

column1: The Problem with Direct Acid-Amine Reaction:
When carboxylic acids are mixed with amines
column2: the initial product is an ammonium carboxylate salt (because acid-base reactions are kinetically much faster than nucleophilic-electrophilic reactions).

column1: However
column2: these salts can be pyrolyzed (heated strongly) to give the desired amides.

column1: This route of amide synthesis is not commonly used in practice; the reaction between an amine and an acid chloride is preferred.
Solution to Avoid Salt Formation:
To avoid forming the ammonium carboxylate salt
column2: one can add a strong base equivalent to the mixture of amine and acid.

column1: This converts the acid to a carboxylate and keeps the amine as a free amine
column2: allowing the nucleophilic addition-elimination (amidification) to proceed.
