Exercise
Consider the following reaction sequence:
A starting material with configuration R
column2: which is a chloro-hydroxy carboxylic acid (containing Cl
column3: OH
column4: and COOH groups with methyl substituents)
column5: reacts with SOCl₂ (thionyl chloride) to give compound A.

column1: Compound A then reacts with C₆H₆ (benzene) in the presence of AlCl₃ (aluminum chloride)
column2: followed by treatment with H₃O⁺ (acidic aqueous workup)
column3: to give a mixture B with the molecular formula C₁₀H₁₀O.

column1: Mixture B then reacts with C₂H₅ONa (sodium ethoxide) in C₂H₅OH (ethanol)
column2: along with C₆H₅CHO (benzaldehyde)
column3: to give compounds C (C₁₇H₁₄O) and C' (C₁₇H₁₄O).

column1: Questions:
Explain the successive reactions (type and balanced equation for each reaction).
Write the mechanism of the reaction leading to C + C' from mixture B.
Specify the structure of the different products A
column2: C
column3: C'
column4: as well as the products constituting mixture B.

column1: Is mixture B optically active?
What type of isomerism is found in compounds C and C'?";;;data/images/671559d991aabe49ee46ddb2_3.png;"Answer
Passage from Starting Material to A: Acid Chloride Formation
The reaction of thionyl chloride (SOCl₂) on the carboxylic acid function converts the -COOH group into an acid chloride (-COCl). This gives compound A.
Important: In this step
column2: the configuration of the asymmetric carbon is not affected. The stereochemistry is preserved.

column1: The structure of A is therefore the same starting material but with the -COOH replaced by -COCl (an acyl chloride)
column2: retaining the R configuration.

column1: Passage from A to B: Double Friedel-Crafts Reaction
Compound B has the molecular formula C₁₀H₁₀O and possesses 6 degrees of unsaturation. Compared to compound A
column2: it no longer contains chlorine atoms. The disappearance of these two chlorine atoms (the Cl on the alkyl chain and the Cl of the acid chloride) indicates that two electrophilic aromatic substitution (SEAr) reactions have been carried out. These are two Friedel-Crafts reactions using the acid chloride A on benzene in the presence of the catalyst AlCl₃.

column1: The first reaction is a Friedel-Crafts acylation. One can note that the chlorine atom on the acyl chloride portion is more reactive than the chlorine on the alkane part of the molecule. Therefore
column2: the acylation occurs first
column3: leading to the formation of a ketone.

column1: The reaction requires at minimum one equivalent of AlCl₃ because AlCl₃ complexes in a stoichiometric manner with the oxygen atom of the carbonyl.
The second reaction is a Friedel-Crafts alkylation
column2: which leads to the formation of a bicyclic derivative (an indanone-type product). The alkylation proceeds through a carbocation intermediate
column3: which can rearrange to a less stable carbocation. However
column4: this rearrangement can actually lead to a thermodynamically more stable six-membered ring product.

column1: There is therefore a competition between thermodynamic control and kinetic control. Depending on the reaction conditions
column2: the composition of the mixture changes. This rearrangement induces a racemization.

column1: Mixture B therefore consists of a racemic mixture of 2-methyl-1-indanone (a bicyclic ketone with a methyl group at the 2-position). Because racemization has occurred during the alkylation step (via the carbocation intermediate)
column2: mixture B is NOT optically active. It is a racemic mixture.

column1: Structure of Mixture B
Mixture B is racemic 2-methyl-1-indanone. It is an indanone (a five-membered ring fused to a benzene ring
column2: with a ketone at position 1) bearing a methyl group at position 2.

column1: Since the carbocation intermediate in the Friedel-Crafts alkylation step loses the stereochemical information
column2: both enantiomers (R and S) of 2-methylindanone are formed in equal amounts. Therefore
column3: mixture B is a racemic mixture and is not optically active.

column1: Passage from B to C and C': Aldol Condensation (Claisen-Schmidt Reaction)
The reaction of mixture B with sodium ethoxide (C₂H₅ONa) in ethanol and benzaldehyde (C₆H₅CHO) is a Claisen-Schmidt condensation (crossed aldol condensation followed by dehydration).
Mechanism:
Step 1 — Deprotonation: Sodium ethoxide (a strong base) deprotonates the alpha carbon of 2-methyl-1-indanone (the carbon bearing the methyl group
column2: at position 2). This removes a proton from the CH₂ group adjacent to the carbonyl
column3: forming an enolate.

column1: Step 2 — Nucleophilic addition: The enolate (acting as a nucleophile) attacks the carbonyl carbon of benzaldehyde (C₆H₅CHO). This forms a new carbon-carbon bond
column2: giving an aldol intermediate (a beta-hydroxy ketone).

column1: Step 3 — Dehydration: The aldol intermediate loses water (elimination of -OH and an adjacent -H) to form the alpha
column2: beta-unsaturated ketone. This dehydration creates a C=C double bond conjugated with both the carbonyl and the phenyl group.

column1: Structures of C and C'
C and C' both have the molecular formula C₁₇H₁₄O. They are the products of the Claisen-Schmidt condensation between 2-methylindanone and benzaldehyde.
The product is 2-(benzylidene)-methyl-1-indanone — specifically
column2: an indanone with a benzylidene group (C₆H₅-CH=) at the 2-position.

column1: C and C' are E/Z isomers (geometric isomers) of each other:
Compound C is the E isomer: The phenyl group (C₆H₅) and the indanone ring system are on opposite sides of the newly formed C=C double bond.
Compound C' is the E isomer (or Z isomer
column2: depending on which is labeled which): The phenyl group and the indanone ring system are on the same side of the C=C double bond.

column1: Type of Isomerism in C and C'

The type of isomerism found in compounds C and C' is E/Z isomerism (geometric isomerism or cis-trans isomerism). This arises because the Claisen-Schmidt condensation creates a new C=C double bond at position 2 of the indanone
column2: and the substituents around this double bond can be arranged in two different spatial orientations (E and Z configurations).

column1: Summary
Starting material (R-chloro-hydroxy acid) reacts with SOCl₂ to give A (the acid chloride
column2: R configuration preserved).

column1: A reacts with benzene and AlCl₃ in a double Friedel-Crafts reaction (first acylation
column2: then intramolecular alkylation) to give mixture B (racemic 2-methyl-1-indanone). B is not optically active due to racemization via the carbocation intermediate.

column1: B reacts with sodium ethoxide and benzaldehyde in a Claisen-Schmidt condensation to give C and C'
column2: which are E and Z geometric isomers of 2-benzylidene-methyl-1-indanone.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;671559d991aabe49ee46ddb2;TRUE;2

column1: ;"Exercise: Synthesis of Pefloxacin
The synthesis of pefloxacin is presented below. The first reaction corresponds to a cyclization during which several reaction steps occur. Using the Pechmann reaction as a guide
column2: specify the course of the reaction. What is the compound that can be distilled to drive the reaction forward? Give the reagents and types of reactions that allow one to arrive at pefloxacin.

column1: Reaction Sequence
Starting materials:
A chloro-aminobenzene derivative (bearing Cl
column2: NH₂
column3: and C₂H₅O groups) reacts with diethyl ethoxymethylenemalonate (CO₂C₂H₅ groups with an ethoxy group) in the presence of Amberlyst-15 (a source of protons / acid catalyst) to give a fluoroquinolone A.

column1: Compound A then undergoes 2 steps to give compound B (which bears F
column2: CO₂H groups on the quinolone ring).

column1: Compound B then undergoes 1 step to give compound C
column2: which is pefloxacin (the final product bearing a piperazine ring with an N-methyl group
column3: F
column4: and a CO₂H group).";;;data/images/6715a3ff81c3e7e7c65b2e0c_2.png;"Obtaining Compound A: Pechmann-type Cyclization

column1: The Amberlyst-15 serves as a source of protons (acid catalyst).
Step-by-step mechanism:
Step 1 — Protonation of the electrophile: The first step consists of protonating the ethoxymethylenemalonate (the starting diester). This protonation forms the carbocation that is most stable
column2: which is the one conjugated with the ethoxy group. The cycle (aromatic ring) is not very reactive because of its electron-withdrawing substituents
column3: making it a poor nucleophile. However
column4: the lone pair on the nitrogen of the aniline (amino group) is sufficiently nucleophilic to react with the carbocation in an addition-elimination mechanism. A first molecule of ethanol is eliminated.

column1: Step 2 — Intramolecular cyclization: One arrives at a compound containing a double bond bearing strongly electron-withdrawing groups that is heavily depleted of electron density. In acidic medium
column2: the ester function is preferentially protonated
column3: leading to a carbocation. This carbocation substitutes onto the aromatic cycle. This reaction is thermodynamically favored because it forms a second six-membered ring. There is elimination of a second molecule of ethanol. The compound that can be distilled off to drive the reaction forward is ethanol (C₂H₅OH). Elimination of a proton (H⁺) leads to the conjugated C=O double bond of the quinolone.

column1: Detailed mechanism description:
The aniline nitrogen (NH₂) attacks the electrophilic carbon of the ethoxymethylenemalonate after protonation. The ethoxy group (OEt) leaves. This forms a new N-C bond with loss of ethanol.
The intermediate now has the nitrogen connected to the carbon chain bearing two ester groups. An intramolecular electrophilic cyclization occurs: in acidic conditions
column2: one of the ester carbonyls is protonated
column3: generating a carbocation that attacks the aromatic ring. This closes the six-membered lactone/lactam ring.

column1: A second molecule of ethanol is lost during this ring closure.
Elimination of H⁺ restores aromaticity and generates the conjugated C=O double bond.
The product is compound A: a fluoroquinolone bearing a diethyl ester group.
The key compound that is distilled off to drive the equilibrium forward is ethanol (C₂H₅OH).
Passage from A to B: Hydrolysis and Amide Formation (2 steps)
The hydrogen atom on the nitrogen atom in compound A is relatively acidic. One can form the amide by addition of a strong base (such as EtO⁻
column2: sodium ethoxide).

column1: The negative charge that develops is delocalized over the ring and the double bond. The amide nitrogen then reacts with iodoethane (C₂H₅I) in an SN2 mechanism.
Step 1 — Saponification/Hydrolysis of the ester:
The ethyl ester group (-CO₂C₂H₅) on the quinolone ring is hydrolyzed to give the free carboxylic acid (-CO₂H). This can be done using base (NaOH) followed by acidification (H₃O⁺)
column2: or directly with acid hydrolysis.

column1: Step 2 — N-Alkylation:

The NH on the quinolone nitrogen is deprotonated by a strong base to form the amide anion. This anion is stabilized by resonance delocalization into the ring. The amide anion then acts as a nucleophile and attacks iodoethane (CH₂CH₃-I) via an SN2 mechanism
column2: forming the N-ethyl bond. This gives compound B with the N-ethyl group and the free carboxylic acid.

column1: Passage from B to C (Pefloxacin): Introduction of the Piperazine Ring (1 step)
This final step involves the introduction of the N-methylpiperazine ring onto the quinolone core.
Reaction type: Nucleophilic Aromatic Substitution (SNAr)
The fluorine atom at the appropriate position on the quinolone ring is displaced by the nitrogen of N-methylpiperazine.
The mechanism is an addition-elimination (SNAr):

The nitrogen lone pair of N-methylpiperazine attacks the carbon bearing the fluorine on the aromatic ring. This carbon is activated toward nucleophilic attack because it is flanked by electron-withdrawing groups (the carbonyl and the ring nitrogen of the quinolone)
column2: making it electron-poor.

column1: A Meisenheimer complex (sigma complex) intermediate is formed
column2: where the aromaticity is temporarily disrupted.

column1: The fluoride ion (F⁻) is expelled as a leaving group
column2: restoring aromaticity.

column1: The product is pefloxacin (compound C): a fluoroquinolone bearing an N-methylpiperazine group
column2: a carboxylic acid
column3: a fluorine (at a different position)
column4: and an N-ethyl group.

column1: Wait — looking at the structure more carefully
column2: the fluorine remains on the ring in pefloxacin. Let me reconsider.

column1: Actually
column2: in the synthesis of pefloxacin
column3: the piperazine displaces one of the substituents (likely a halogen or activated leaving group at a specific position) on the quinolone ring via nucleophilic aromatic substitution. The fluorine at position 6 is retained in the final product (it is a characteristic feature of fluoroquinolone antibiotics). The piperazine is introduced at position 7 by displacing a different leaving group (likely the chlorine or another halogen at that position).

column1: Corrected Step:

The N-methylpiperazine reacts with compound B at the position bearing a suitable leaving group (the chlorine atom at position 7) via nucleophilic aromatic substitution (SNAr). The chlorine is displaced by the piperazine nitrogen. The fluorine at position 6 remains intact.
This gives compound C
column2: which is pefloxacin.

column1: Summary of the Complete Synthesis
Starting material + diethyl ethoxymethylenemalonate
column2: with Amberlyst-15 (acid catalyst) gives compound A via Pechmann-type cyclization. Ethanol is distilled off to drive the reaction.

column1: A undergoes ester hydrolysis (giving free -CO₂H) and N-alkylation with iodoethane (SN2) in 2 steps to give compound B.
B undergoes nucleophilic aromatic substitution (SNAr) with N-methylpiperazine (displacement of Cl) in 1 step to give compound C
column2: which is pefloxacin.

column1: Types of reactions involved:
Pechmann-type cyclization (electrophilic addition-elimination
column2: intramolecular SEAr) — to form A

column1: Ester hydrolysis (saponification) — A to B
N-Alkylation via SN2 — A to B
Nucleophilic aromatic substitution (SNAr) — B to C (pefloxacin)";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;671559d991aabe49ee46ddb2;TRUE;1
;Complete this reaction;;;data/images/6715a3ff81c3e7e7c65b2e0c_3.png;"Answer: Mechanism of Cyclization Reaction

This reaction sequence describes the transformation of an ortho-methoxyphenyl amine derivative with methyl vinyl ketone (MVK) to ultimately form a cyclic product C (an isoquinoline derivative) through a series of steps.
Step 1: 1
column2: 4-Conjugate Addition (Michael Addition)

column1: The starting amine (an ortho-methoxyphenylethylamine
column2: bearing an NH₂ group and an OMe group on the aromatic ring) reacts with methyl vinyl ketone (CH₂=CH-CO-CH₃).

column1: The nitrogen lone pair of the amine acts as a nucleophile and attacks the beta carbon of the methyl vinyl ketone in a 1
column2: 4-conjugate addition (also called a Michael addition
column3: abbreviated AN 1
column4: 4 in the image).

column1: The nitrogen adds to the terminal carbon of the double bond (the beta position relative to the carbonyl)
column2: and the electrons shift to the oxygen
column3: forming an enolate intermediate.

column1: The enolate intermediate has a negative charge on the oxygen of the former carbonyl.
Step 2: Proton Transfer to Give the Ketone

The enolate intermediate undergoes protonation on the oxygen to regenerate the carbonyl group (C=O). This gives an open-chain amino ketone: a molecule where the nitrogen is now connected through a chain to a methyl ketone group.

The product at this stage is a secondary amine bearing a pendant chain ending in a ketone: the nitrogen (NH) is connected to the ethyl-methoxyphenyl part on one side and to a CH₂CH₂COCH₃ chain on the other side.
Step 3: Tautomerism

The amino ketone undergoes tautomerism. This is a keto-enol type equilibrium. The enol form can tautomerize to give the keto form (compound A). Compound A is the open-chain amino ketone in its most stable keto form
column2: with the structure:

column1: An ortho-methoxyphenylethyl group connected through NH to a butanone chain (with the methyl ketone at the end).
Step 4: Intramolecular Cyclization — Formation of the Iminium Ion
Compound A now undergoes intramolecular cyclization. In acidic conditions (H⁺)
column2: the ketone carbonyl is activated
column3: and the nitrogen lone pair attacks the carbonyl carbon intramolecularly.

column1: This is an intramolecular nucleophilic addition of the nitrogen onto the ketone. The nitrogen attacks the carbonyl carbon
column2: forming a new C-N bond and closing a six-membered ring. Water is lost in the process.

column1: This generates an iminium ion intermediate — a positively charged nitrogen in the newly formed ring. The ring now contains the nitrogen as part of a six-membered ring system.
Step 5: Intramolecular Electrophilic Substitution (SE)
The iminium ion intermediate then undergoes an intramolecular electrophilic aromatic substitution (abbreviated SE in the image).
The electrophilic iminium carbon (C=N⁺) acts as the electrophile
column2: and the electron-rich aromatic ring (activated by the OMe group
column3: which is an electron-donating group) acts as the nucleophile.

column1: The aromatic ring attacks the iminium carbon
column2: forming a new C-C bond and closing a second ring. This creates the bicyclic tetrahydroisoquinoline framework.

column1: The methoxy group (OMe) on the ring plays a crucial role here: it activates the ring toward electrophilic substitution and directs the cyclization to occur at the correct position (ortho/para to OMe).
A proton is lost from the ring carbon to restore partial aromaticity
column2: and water (H₂O) is lost during the overall process.

column1: This gives compound B: a tetrahydroisoquinoline derivative bearing a methyl group and a hydroxyl group
column2: with the OMe substituent on the aromatic ring.

column1: Step 6: Oxidation to Give Compound C
Compound B is then oxidized using PhNO₂ (nitrobenzene) as the oxidizing agent.
The oxidation removes two hydrogen atoms (H₂) from compound B
column2: converting the partially saturated ring into a more aromatic/oxidized system.

column1: Specifically
column2: the dihydro ring system in B is oxidized (aromatized) to give compound C. Nitrobenzene acts as a mild oxidizing agent
column3: accepting the two hydrogen atoms.

column1: Compound C is the final product: a 1-methyl-6-methoxyisoquinoline (or a similar substituted isoquinoline). It is a fully or partially aromatic bicyclic nitrogen-containing heterocycle with:
A methyl group (Me) at position 1
A methoxy group (OMe) on the aromatic ring
Summary of the Entire Sequence

column2: 4-Conjugate addition (Michael addition): The amine adds to methyl vinyl ketone at the beta position.

column1: Protonation of enolate: The enolate is protonated to give the amino ketone.
Tautomerism: Keto-enol equilibrium gives compound A (the keto form).
Intramolecular cyclization: Under acidic conditions
column2: the nitrogen attacks the ketone carbonyl intramolecularly
column3: forming an iminium ion and closing the first ring. Water is lost.

column1: Intramolecular electrophilic aromatic substitution: The iminium ion is attacked by the electron-rich aromatic ring (activated by OMe)
column2: closing the second ring to form compound B (a tetrahydroisoquinoline).

column1: Oxidation: Compound B is oxidized by nitrobenzene (PhNO₂) to give compound C
column2: the aromatic isoquinoline product.

column1: This overall transformation is a classic example of the Pictet-Spengler reaction (or a closely related cyclization)
column2: which is a widely used method for constructing isoquinoline alkaloid frameworks.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;671559d991aabe49ee46ddb2;TRUE;2

column1: ;Use the attached image to answer the following question. What is the IUPAC name of the product of the reaction?;;;data/images/6715bb667faaf2a75fbb0df6_2.png;"Answer: Reaction with Formamide to Form a Fused Heterocycle
Starting Material
The starting material is a bicyclic compound: a pyridine ring fused to a cyclohexene-type bridge (specifically a 5
column2: 8-ethano bridged system). This molecule bears two functional groups:

column1: An amino group (NH₂) at one position on the pyridine ring
An ethyl ester group (OEt) at the adjacent position
column2: which is part of a carbonyl (C=O) function (making it an ester or a lactam/amide ester)

column1: More precisely
column2: the starting material is an amino ester derivative of an ethano-bridged pyridine.

column1: Reaction Conditions
The starting material is heated with formamide (HCONH₂) at 190 degrees Celsius for 10 hours. The reaction proceeds with a yield of 52 percent.
Product
The product is a tricyclic compound containing a newly formed pyrimidine ring fused to the existing pyridine ring
column2: with the ethano bridge maintained. The product contains an NH group in the newly formed ring.

column1: What Happens in the Reaction
Formamide (HCONH₂) acts as both a source of a one-carbon unit (the formyl group
column2: HC=O) and a nitrogen source.

column1: At high temperature (190 degrees Celsius)
column2: the formamide reacts with the amino group (NH₂) and the ester/carbonyl group on the starting material. The nitrogen of the amino group and the carbon from formamide combine to close a new six-membered ring
column3: forming a pyrimidine ring.

column1: Specifically:
The amino group (NH₂) on the pyridine ring reacts with formamide. The nitrogen of the amine attacks the carbonyl carbon of formamide
column2: forming a new N-C bond.

column1: The ester group (OEt with C=O) participates in the ring closure. Ethanol (EtOH) is eliminated as a byproduct.
A new six-membered pyrimidine ring is formed
column2: fused to the existing pyridine ring. This creates a pyrido-pyrimidine system.

column1: The product retains the ethano bridge from the starting material and has an NH group in the newly formed pyrimidine ring
column2: along with a ketone (C=O
column3: the 4-one).

column1: IUPAC Name of the Product
The IUPAC name of the product of this reaction is:

column2: 8-ethanopyrido[3
column3: 2-d]pyrimidin-4-one

column1: Breaking down this name:
Pyrido[3
column2: 2-d]pyrimidine: This indicates a fused bicyclic system consisting of a pyridine ring and a pyrimidine ring. The notation [3
column3: 2-d] specifies the positions and face of fusion between the two rings. The pyridine bonds at positions 3 and 2 are fused to the d-face of the pyrimidine.

column1: 4-one: There is a ketone (carbonyl
column2: C=O) at position 4 of the pyrimidine ring.
8-ethano: There is an ethylene bridge (-CH₂-CH₂-) connecting positions 5 and 8 of the ring system. This is the bridged portion carried over from the starting material.

column1: Summary
An amino ester derivative of an ethano-bridged pyridine reacts with formamide at high temperature (190 degrees Celsius
column2: 10 hours) to undergo a cyclization reaction. The formamide provides the one-carbon unit needed to close a new pyrimidine ring
column3: which fuses onto the existing pyridine ring. Ethanol is lost during the reaction. The final product is 5
column4: 8-ethanopyrido[3
column5: 2-d]pyrimidin-4-one
column6: obtained in 52 percent yield. This is a bridged pyrido-pyrimidine heterocyclic compound containing an NH group and a carbonyl (4-one) in the pyrimidine ring.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;6715bb667faaf2a75fbb0df6;TRUE;1

column1: ;Use the attached image to answer the following question. What is the IUPAC name of the product of the reaction?;;;data/images/6715bb667faaf2a75fbb0df6_3.png;"Answer: Reaction with Urea to Form a Fused Pyrimidine
Starting Material
The starting material is a 3-aminopyridine-2-carboxylic acid (also known as 3-amino-2-picolinic acid). It is a pyridine ring bearing two substituents on adjacent positions:
A carboxylic acid group (COOH) at position 2 of the pyridine ring
An amino group (NH₂) at position 3 of the pyridine ring
These two functional groups are on neighboring carbons
column2: which is essential for the subsequent ring-closing reaction.

column1: Reaction Conditions
The starting material is heated with urea (H₂N-CO-NH₂) using 5.0 equivalents of urea at 280 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes. The reaction proceeds with an excellent yield of 97 percent.
Product
The product is a bicyclic compound where a new pyrimidine ring has been fused onto the existing pyridine ring. The product contains two hydroxyl groups (OH) on the newly formed pyrimidine ring
column2: one at each position adjacent to the nitrogen atoms.

column1: What Happens in the Reaction
Urea serves as a bifunctional reagent providing two nitrogen atoms and one carbon unit (the carbonyl carbon of urea) for the construction of the new pyrimidine ring.
At the very high temperature of 280 degrees Celsius
column2: the following steps occur:

column1: The amino group (NH₂) at position 3 of the pyridine reacts with one of the carbonyl-adjacent nitrogens of urea. A new N-C bond is formed between the ring nitrogen and the carbon of urea. Ammonia (NH₃) is released as a byproduct.
The carboxylic acid group (COOH) at position 2 of the pyridine also participates in the ring closure. It reacts with the other nitrogen of urea
column2: forming a second new bond. Water (H₂O) is eliminated as a byproduct.

column1: These two bond-forming events close a new six-membered ring
column2: creating the pyrimidine ring fused to the pyridine ring.

column1: The product contains two hydroxyl groups (OH) on the pyrimidine ring. These OH groups exist because the carbonyl of the original carboxylic acid and the carbonyl of urea are incorporated into the ring system and exist in their hydroxyl tautomeric forms (the enol/hydroxyl forms rather than the keto/amide forms
column2: although in solution both tautomers may exist in equilibrium).

column1: IUPAC Name of the Product
The IUPAC name of the product is:

column2: 4-dihydroxypyrido[2
column3: 3-d]pyrimidine

column1: Breaking down this name:
Pyrido[2
column2: 3-d]pyrimidine: This describes a fused bicyclic ring system consisting of a pyridine ring and a pyrimidine ring. The notation [2
column3: 3-d] specifies that the fusion occurs between positions 2 and 3 of the pyridine ring and the d-face of the pyrimidine ring. In other words
column4: the bond shared between the two rings connects carbons 2 and 3 of the pyridine with the corresponding edge of the pyrimidine.

column2: 4-dihydroxy: There are two hydroxyl groups (OH) on the pyrimidine ring at positions 2 and 4. Position 2 corresponds to the carbon derived from the urea carbonyl
column3: and position 4 corresponds to the carbon derived from the original carboxylic acid group of the starting material.

column1: It is worth noting that these hydroxyl groups may also be written in their keto (oxo) tautomeric forms as 2
column2: 4-dioxo (meaning two C=O groups instead of two C-OH groups). The compound could equally be named pyrido[2
column3: 3-d]pyrimidine-2
column5: 3H)-dione in its diketo form. However
column6: the name given here uses the dihydroxy nomenclature

column1: Summary
3-Aminopyridine-2-carboxylic acid reacts with 5 equivalents of urea at 280 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes to give 2
column2: 4-dihydroxypyrido[2
column3: 3-d]pyrimidine in 97 percent yield. The urea provides the nitrogen and carbon atoms needed to construct a new pyrimidine ring
column4: which fuses onto the pyridine ring at the 2
column5: 3-positions. The two hydroxyl groups on the pyrimidine ring originate from the urea carbonyl and the carboxylic acid of the starting material. This is an efficient one-step thermal cyclization that builds a fused pyrido-pyrimidine heterocyclic system.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;6715bb667faaf2a75fbb0df6;TRUE;2

column1: ;Explain the following rearrangement:;;;data/images/6716aa268f636721baad8695_2.png;"
Answer: Claisen Rearrangement and Homosigmatropic [1
column2: 5] Rearrangement

column1: Starting Material
The starting material is an allyl aryl ether — specifically
column2: an allyl phenyl ether derivative. It consists of a benzene ring connected through an oxygen atom to an allylic chain. The allylic chain bears methyl substituents. More precisely
column3: the starting material has:

column1: A phenyl ring with an oxygen (O) attached
The oxygen is connected to a CH₂ group
This CH₂ is connected to a carbon-carbon double bond
The double bond and adjacent carbons bear methyl groups (H₃C groups at the delta and gamma positions)
Step 1: Normal Claisen Rearrangement
The first transformation is a normal Claisen rearrangement. This is a [3
column2: 3]-sigmatropic rearrangement.

column1: In this rearrangement:
The allyl vinyl ether system undergoes a concerted pericyclic reaction through a six-membered chair-like transition state.
The carbon-oxygen bond (the O-CH₂ bond connecting the oxygen to the allyl group) breaks.
Simultaneously
column2: a new carbon-carbon bond forms between the gamma carbon of the allyl group and the ortho position of the aromatic ring.

column1: The oxygen
column2: which was originally part of the ether linkage
column3: becomes a carbonyl-like group (initially forming a cyclohexadienone intermediate).

column1: The product of this normal Claisen rearrangement is a cyclohexadienone intermediate. This intermediate has:
The oxygen now as part of a hydroxyl/enol/ketone on the ring
The allyl chain now directly bonded to the ring at the ortho position
A dearomatized cyclohexadienone ring system
The CH-CH fragment (from the former double bond) now connected to the ring
Methyl groups (H₃C) retained from the original allyl chain
The key bonds that changed are: the O-C(allyl) bond broke
column2: and a new C(ring)-C(allyl) bond formed
column3: both in a concerted [3
column4: 3] fashion. The alpha carbon of the original allyl group is now bonded to the ortho carbon of the ring.

column1: Step 2: Homosigmatropic [1
column2: 5] Rearrangement

column1: The cyclohexadienone product from the Claisen rearrangement then undergoes a second rearrangement: a homosigmatropic [1
column2: 5] shift.

column1: In this rearrangement:
A hydrogen atom migrates from one position to another within the molecule in a [1
column2: 5] sigmatropic shift.

column1: Specifically
column2: the allyl substituent that was placed at the ortho position migrates. The bond connectivity rearranges so that the substituent effectively moves from the ortho position to create a new arrangement.

column1: The product of this homosigmatropic [1
column2: 5] rearrangement is shown in two equivalent representations:

column1: First representation: A cyclopentadiene-type ring (a five-membered ring with the oxygen) bearing the methyl groups and the chain substituents. The molecule has:
An oxygen connected to a five-membered ring portion
A CH₃ group
A CH group
CH₂ groups
Additional CH₃ groups from the original allyl chain
Second (equivalent) representation: The same molecule drawn differently to show the connectivity more clearly
column2: with the aromatic ring
column3: the oxygen
column4: and the rearranged substituent chain.

column1: Final Product: Tautomerization to Phenol
The final product is shown at the bottom right of the image. After the rearrangements
column2: the molecule tautomerizes (keto-enol tautomerism) to regenerate the aromatic ring and give a phenol.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;6716aa268f636721baad8695;TRUE;1

column1: ;Explain the following rearrangement:;;;data/images/6716aa268f636721baad8695_3.png;"Answer: Acid-Catalyzed Rearrangement of a Bicyclic Diol to a Spiro Ketone
Starting Material
The starting material is a bicyclo[4.3.0]nonane system (a decalin-like bicyclic compound consisting of a six-membered ring fused to a five-membered ring). It bears two hydroxyl groups (OH
column2: OH) on adjacent carbons at positions 5 and 6
column3: making it a vicinal diol (1
column4: 2-diol). The carbons are numbered 1 through 9 around the bicyclic framework.

column1: Product

The product is a spiro ketone — specifically a spiro compound where a five-membered ring and a six-membered ring share a single carbon atom (the spiro center). The product has a carbonyl group (C=O) on the six-membered ring. A new bond (shown in green in the image) has formed to create the spiro junction
column2: while an old bond (shown in black in the starting material) has broken during the rearrangement.

column1: Reaction Conditions
The reaction is carried out in the presence of H⁺ (acid catalyst). The acid promotes the rearrangement of the bicyclic diol into the spiro ketone.
Mechanism: Step-by-Step Description
Step 1: Protonation of One Hydroxyl Group
In acidic conditions
column2: one of the two hydroxyl groups (OH) on the vicinal diol is protonated to form a good leaving group (water
column3: H₂O). Specifically
column4: the hydroxyl at position 6 is protonated to give an oxonium ion (OH₂⁺).

column1: The starting diol with both OH groups on the fused five-membered ring now has one OH and one OH₂⁺.
Step 2: Loss of Water and Formation of a Carbocation
The protonated hydroxyl group departs as water (H₂O)
column2: generating a carbocation at position 6. This carbocation is adjacent to the remaining hydroxyl group at position 5.

column1: At this stage
column2: the molecule is a bicyclic system with a carbocation at one position and a hydroxyl group on the neighboring carbon.

column1: Step 3: 1
column2: 2-Alkyl Shift (Semi-Pinacol Rearrangement)

column1: This is the key step of the rearrangement. The bond between carbons 1 and 6 (the black bond that breaks
column2: which is part of the ring junction of the original bicyclic system) undergoes a 1
column3: 2-alkyl shift.

column1: The carbon-carbon bond migrates: the bonding electrons of the C1-C6 bond shift to form a new bond between C1 and the carbocation center. This migration simultaneously:
Breaks the old ring junction bond (the black bond between C1 and C6 in the starting material)
Forms a new bond (the green bond in the product) creating the spiro center
Shifts the carbocation to a new position
This is essentially a semi-pinacol rearrangement: a 1
column2: 2-shift occurring in a beta-hydroxy carbocation (a carbocation adjacent to a hydroxyl group). The driving force is the migration of an alkyl group to the carbocation center
column3: which relieves strain and leads to a more stable product.

column1: Step 4: Formation of the Ketone
After the alkyl shift
column2: the remaining hydroxyl group at position 5 is now on a carbon that is adjacent to the new carbocation center. The proton on the hydroxyl oxygen is lost (deprotonation)
column3: and the electrons from the O-H bond form the C=O double bond
column4: generating the ketone (carbonyl group).

column1: Alternatively
column2: one can view this as: after the rearrangement
column3: the oxygen loses a proton to give the stable carbonyl product.

column1: The result is a spiro ketone where the five-membered ring and six-membered ring share one common carbon atom (the spiro center)
column2: and the carbonyl group is on the six-membered ring.

column1: Summary of Bond Changes
In the starting material (bicyclic diol):
The black bond (C1-C6 bond at the ring junction) breaks during the rearrangement.
In the product (spiro ketone):
The green bond (new C-C bond forming the spiro junction) is created.
One of the OH groups has been converted to a C=O (ketone).
The other OH group was lost as water after protonation.

The overall transformation converts a fused bicyclic vicinal diol into a spiro ketone through an acid-catalyzed semi-pinacol rearrangement. The ring system changes from a fused bicycle (two rings sharing an edge/two atoms) to a spiro compound (two rings sharing only one atom). This rearrangement is driven by the formation of a stable carbonyl group and the relief of ring strain.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;6716aa268f636721baad8695;TRUE;2

column1: The Reaction
The two starting materials are:
Starting material 1: Phenylacetic acid. This is a benzene ring attached to a CH₂ group which bears a carboxylic acid function (COOH). It can also be described as C₆H₅-CH₂-COOH.
Starting material 2: (Chloromethyl)phenyl sulfide. This is a benzene ring attached to a sulfur atom
column2: which is in turn connected to a CH₂ group bearing a chlorine atom. It can be described as C₆H₅-S-CH₂-Cl.

column1: Reagents: Triethylamine (Et₃N) as a base
column2: in DMF (N
column3: N-dimethylformamide) as the solvent.

column1: What Happens in the Reaction
Step 1: Triethylamine (Et₃N)
column2: acting as a base
column3: deprotonates the carboxylic acid group (COOH) of phenylacetic acid. This generates the carboxylate anion (COO⁻)
column4: which is a good nucleophile.

column1: Step 2: The carboxylate anion attacks the electrophilic CH₂ carbon of (chloromethyl)phenyl sulfide in an SN2 (nucleophilic substitution) reaction. The chlorine atom departs as a chloride ion (Cl⁻)
column2: and a new O-C bond forms between the oxygen of the carboxylate and the methylene carbon.

column1: The result is an ester linkage: the carboxylate oxygen is now bonded to the CH₂ group
column2: which is still connected to the sulfur and the phenyl group on the other side.

column1: Product

On one side

column3: which is connected to a carbonyl (C=O)
column4: which is connected to an oxygen

Position 1: The ester oxygen
The oxygen connects to the CH₂ group (from the former chloromethyl group)
The sulfur atom bridges to the second phenyl ring (positions 8 through 11)

column1: The Reaction
The two starting materials are:

Starting material 1: Acryloyl chloride (also called acrylic acid chloride). This is a three-carbon molecule consisting of a vinyl group (CH₂=CH-) connected to a carbonyl bearing a chlorine atom (-COCl). Its structure is CH₂=CH-COCl. It is a reactive acid chloride with an alpha
column2: beta-unsaturated system.

column1: Starting material 2: Thiophenol. This is a benzene ring bearing a thiol group (-SH). Its structure is C₆H₅-SH. The sulfur atom carries a lone pair and is a good nucleophile.
Reagents and conditions: Pyridine (Pyr) as a base
column2: DMAP (4-dimethylaminopyridine) as a nucleophilic catalyst
column3: at 0 degrees Celsius for 3 hours
column4: in dichloromethane (CH₂Cl₂) as the solvent.

column1: What Happens in the Reaction
This reaction involves two distinct steps
column2: both involving the thiophenol as a nucleophile:

column1: Step 1: Thioester formation (substitution at the acyl chloride)

The first equivalent of thiophenol acts as a nucleophile and attacks the electrophilic carbonyl carbon of the acryloyl chloride. Pyridine acts as a base to neutralize the HCl that is generated. DMAP acts as a nucleophilic catalyst to accelerate the acylation reaction. The chlorine is displaced
column2: and a new S-C bond forms between the sulfur of thiophenol and the carbonyl carbon. This creates a thioester linkage (C₆H₅-S-CO-).

column1: At this point
column2: the intermediate product is phenyl acrylate thioester: C₆H₅-S-CO-CH=CH₂. This is an alpha
column3: beta-unsaturated thioester.

column1: Step 2: Thia-Michael addition (1
column2: 4-conjugate addition)

column1: A second equivalent of thiophenol then performs a conjugate addition (Michael addition or thia-Michael addition) onto the alpha
column2: beta-unsaturated thioester. The sulfur nucleophile of the second thiophenol attacks the beta carbon (the terminal CH₂ of the vinyl group) in a 1
column3: 4-fashion. The electrons shift through the conjugated system.

column1: After protonation
column2: this gives the final product where the second phenylsulfanyl group (C₆H₅-S-) is now attached to the beta carbon of the propanoyl chain.

column1: Molar mass: 274.40 g per mol
IUPAC name: phenyl 3-(phenylsulfanyl)propanethioate
Breaking down the IUPAC name:

Propanethioate: This indicates a three-carbon chain (propanoic acid) forming a thioester. The suffix ""thioate"" means the ester bond is through a sulfur atom (C-CO-S) rather than through an oxygen (which would be a regular ester).
Phenyl: This is the phenyl group (C₆H₅) attached to the sulfur of the thioester bond. So the thioester part is -CO-S-C₆H₅.
3-(phenylsulfanyl): At position 3 of the propanoyl chain (the carbon farthest from the carbonyl)
column2: there is a phenylsulfanyl group. ""Phenylsulfanyl"" means a phenyl group connected through a sulfur atom (C₆H₅-S-). This is the group that was introduced by the thia-Michael addition.

column1: So the full name describes a thioester of phenyl thiol with 3-(phenylsulfanyl)propanoic acid.
Summary

Acryloyl chloride reacts with thiophenol in the presence of pyridine and DMAP at 0 degrees Celsius. The first step is a nucleophilic acyl substitution where thiophenol displaces the chloride to form a thioester (phenyl acrylate thioester). The second step is a thia-Michael addition where a second molecule of thiophenol adds in a 1
column2: 4-conjugate fashion to the alpha
column3: beta-unsaturated thioester. The final product is phenyl 3-(phenylsulfanyl)propanethioate
column4: with the molecular formula C₁₅H₁₄OS₂ and a molar mass of 274.40 g per mol. This corresponds to structure A among the proposed options.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;671808958b88f01935b5825a;TRUE;2

column2: which means there is no symmetry in the molecule (all 8 carbons of C₈H₈O₃ are chemically non-equivalent). This is consistent with the proposed structure of vanillin.

column1: The signals are assigned as follows:
Signal at approximately 190 ppm — CHO:
This is the aldehyde carbon. Aldehyde carbons typically appear in the 190 to 205 ppm range.
Signal at approximately 150 to 155 ppm — C-OH (aromatic):
This is the aromatic carbon bearing the hydroxyl group (C-OH). Aromatic carbons attached to oxygen are deshielded and appear in the 140 to 160 ppm region.
Signal at approximately 145 to 150 ppm — C-OR (aromatic):
This is the aromatic carbon bearing the methoxy group (C-OCH₃). It also appears in the 140 to 160 ppm region
column2: slightly different from C-OH due to the different electronic effect of the methoxy versus hydroxyl group.

column1: Signals at approximately 110 to 130 ppm — C aromatic (CH carbons):
These signals correspond to the aromatic CH carbons and the quaternary aromatic carbon bearing the aldehyde. Multiple signals appear in this region for the different aromatic carbons.
Signal at approximately 55 ppm — OMe:
This is the carbon of the methoxy group (OCH₃). Methoxy carbons attached to aromatic rings typically appear around 55 to 56 ppm.
Justification from IR Spectrum
Two IR spectra are provided: one as a KBr pellet (solid state) and one as a dilute solution in CCl₄.
IR Spectrum in KBr Pellet
Broad absorption around 3000 to 3500 cm⁻¹ — ν(OH) associated:
A broad band in this region corresponds to the O-H stretching vibration. The broadness indicates that the OH groups are involved in hydrogen bonding (associated OH). In the solid state (KBr pellet)
column2: intermolecular hydrogen bonding is extensive
column3: leading to a very broad absorption.

column1: Absorption around 2850 to 2960 cm⁻¹ — ν(CH alkyl) and δs(CH₃):
These absorptions correspond to the C-H stretching vibrations of the methoxy CH₃ group. The symmetric stretching (δs CH₃) is also observed in this region.
Absorption around 2750 to 2850 cm⁻¹ — ν(CH CHO):
This is a characteristic absorption of the aldehyde C-H stretching vibration. Aldehyde C-H stretches typically appear as two bands in the 2700 to 2850 cm⁻¹ region (due to Fermi resonance).
Strong absorption around 1680 to 1700 cm⁻¹ — ν(C=O):
This is the carbonyl stretching vibration of the aldehyde. The aldehyde C=O typically absorbs around 1720 cm⁻¹
column2: but conjugation with the aromatic ring lowers the frequency to approximately 1680 to 1700 cm⁻¹.

column1: Absorptions around 1580 to 1600 cm⁻¹ — ν(C=C aromatic):
These correspond to the aromatic C=C stretching vibrations of the benzene ring.
Absorption around 1450 cm⁻¹ — δas(CH₃):
This is the asymmetric bending vibration of the methoxy CH₃ group.
Absorption around 1250 to 1300 cm⁻¹ — ν(C-O ether):
This corresponds to the C-O stretching vibration of the methoxy group (Ar-O-CH₃).
Absorption around 1100 to 1200 cm⁻¹ — ν(C-O Ar-OH):
This corresponds to the C-O stretching vibration of the phenolic C-OH bond.
Absorption around 800 to 900 cm⁻¹ — δ(C=C-H):
This corresponds to the out-of-plane bending vibrations of the aromatic C-H bonds
column2: which can give information about the substitution pattern of the ring.

column1: IR Spectrum in Dilute CCl₄ Solution
Sharp absorption around 3600 cm⁻¹ — ν(OH) free:
In dilute solution
column2: the hydroxyl group is no longer extensively hydrogen bonded (free OH). This gives a sharp
column3: narrow absorption at higher wavenumber compared to the broad associated OH band seen in the KBr pellet.

column1: Absorption around 3050 cm⁻¹ — ν(CH unsaturated):
This corresponds to the aromatic C-H stretching vibrations (unsaturated/sp² C-H).
Absorption around 2850 to 2960 cm⁻¹ — ν(CH alkyl):
C-H stretching of the methoxy group.
Absorption around 2750 to 2850 cm⁻¹ — ν(CH CHO):
Aldehyde C-H stretch.
All other absorptions (C=O
column2: C=C aromatic
column3: CH₃ bending
column4: C-O ether
column5: C-O Ar-OH
column6: C=C-H bending) appear at similar positions as in the KBr spectrum.

column1: The key difference between the two IR spectra is the OH stretching region: in KBr pellet
column2: the OH is broad and at lower wavenumber (associated/hydrogen bonded)
column3: while in dilute CCl₄ solution
column4: the OH is sharp and at higher wavenumber (free
column5: non-hydrogen bonded).

column4: 4-trisubstitution)

column6: and a methoxy singlet (3H around 3.9 ppm).

column3: two oxygenated aromatic carbons around 145 to 155 ppm

column1: ;"Based on the following spectra
column2: determine the structure of the compound with the molecular formula C₉H₁₁NO.

column1: Justify your answer by indicating on the spectra the assignment of the NMR signals and the characteristic IR absorptions.";;;data/images/6719c431d5ad96a75c350fa5_3.png;"Answer: Structure Determination of Phenacetin (C₁₀H₁₃NO₂)
Note: The question header mentions C₉H₁₁NO
column2: but the actual compound identified from the spectra has the molecular formula C₁₀H₁₃NO₂. The image confirms the compound is phenacetin.

column1: Proposed Structure: Phenacetin
The compound is phenacetin (also known as 4-ethoxyacetanilide or N-(4-ethoxyphenyl)acetamide).
The structure consists of:
A benzene ring substituted in the para pattern (positions 1 and 4)
At position 1: An amide group
column2: specifically an acetamide (NH-CO-CH₃). The nitrogen is bonded to a hydrogen (NH)
column3: and the carbonyl is bonded to a methyl group (COCH₃).

column1: At position 4: An ethoxy group (O-CH₂-CH₃). The oxygen is bonded to the ring and to an ethyl chain.
Reading through the molecule: CH₃-CH₂-O-C₆H₄-NH-CO-CH₃
The compound is para-substituted
column2: meaning the ethoxy group and the acetamide group are on opposite sides of the benzene ring (positions 1 and 4).

column1: Justification from ¹H NMR Spectrum
The ¹H NMR spectrum shows the following signals
column2: listed from downfield to upfield:

column1: Broad singlet around 9 to 10 ppm — NH (1H):

This broad singlet corresponds to the amide NH proton. Amide NH protons typically appear as broad signals due to partial quadrupolar coupling with nitrogen and hydrogen bonding effects. The broadness is characteristic of an NH involved in an amide bond.
Doublet around 7.3 to 7.5 ppm — 2H aromatic:
These are two aromatic protons on the benzene ring. In a para-disubstituted benzene
column2: the four aromatic protons appear as two sets of two protons each
column3: with each set appearing as a doublet. This first doublet (more downfield) corresponds to the two aromatic protons that are ortho to the more electron-withdrawing substituent (the amide group). These protons are slightly more deshielded.

column1: Doublet around 6.8 to 7.0 ppm — 2H aromatic:

These are the other two aromatic protons on the benzene ring. This second doublet (more upfield) corresponds to the two aromatic protons that are ortho to the more electron-donating substituent (the ethoxy group). These protons are slightly more shielded. Together with the first doublet
column2: this pattern of two doublets in the aromatic region is characteristic of a para-disubstituted benzene ring (AA'BB' pattern appearing as two apparent doublets).

column1: Quartet around 4.0 ppm — 2H
column2: O-CH₂-CH₃:

column1: This quartet corresponds to the methylene group (CH₂) of the ethoxy group. It appears as a quartet because the two CH₂ protons are coupled to the three adjacent CH₃ protons (n+1 rule: 3 neighbors gives 4 peaks
column2: a quartet). The chemical shift of approximately 4.0 ppm is consistent with a CH₂ group attached to an oxygen atom (O-CH₂)
column3: which deshields the protons.

column1: Singlet around 2.1 ppm — 3H
column2: CH₃-CO:

column1: This singlet corresponds to the methyl group attached to the carbonyl of the acetamide (CH₃-CO-NH). It appears as a singlet because the methyl group has no adjacent protons to couple with (the neighboring carbon is the carbonyl carbon
column2: which bears no hydrogen). The chemical shift of approximately 2.1 ppm is typical for a methyl group alpha to a carbonyl.

column1: Triplet around 1.4 ppm — 3H
column2: O-CH₂-CH₃:

column1: This triplet corresponds to the terminal methyl group (CH₃) of the ethoxy group. It appears as a triplet because the three CH₃ protons are coupled to the two adjacent CH₂ protons (n+1 rule: 2 neighbors gives 3 peaks
column2: a triplet). The chemical shift of approximately 1.4 ppm is typical for a methyl group one carbon away from an oxygen.

column1: Justification from ¹³C Proton-Decoupled NMR Spectrum
The ¹³C{¹H} NMR spectrum shows the following signals:
Signal around 168 ppm — N-CO:
This is the carbonyl carbon of the amide group (N-CO-CH₃). Amide carbonyls typically appear around 165 to 175 ppm.
Signal around 155 ppm — O-C aromatic:
This is the aromatic carbon bearing the ethoxy group (C-O-CH₂CH₃). Aromatic carbons bonded to oxygen are significantly deshielded and appear in the 150 to 160 ppm range.
Signal around 140 ppm — N-C aromatic:
This is the aromatic carbon bearing the nitrogen of the amide group (C-NH-COCH₃). Aromatic carbons bonded to nitrogen are deshielded and appear around 135 to 145 ppm.
Signal around 115 to 120 ppm — C-H aromatic:
These signals correspond to the aromatic CH carbons. In a para-disubstituted benzene
column2: there are two types of aromatic CH carbons (those ortho to nitrogen and those ortho to oxygen). These appear in the typical aromatic CH region of 110 to 130 ppm.

column1: Signal around 63 ppm — O-CH₂:
This is the methylene carbon of the ethoxy group (O-CH₂-CH₃). Carbons bonded to oxygen typically appear around 60 to 70 ppm.
Signal around 24 ppm — CH₃-CO:
This is the methyl carbon of the acetyl group (CH₃-CO). Methyl carbons alpha to a carbonyl appear around 20 to 25 ppm.
Signal around 15 ppm — CH₃:
This is the terminal methyl carbon of the ethoxy group (O-CH₂-CH₃). Terminal methyl carbons appear in the 10 to 20 ppm range.
Justification from IR Spectrum (KBr Pellet)
The IR spectrum shows the following characteristic absorptions:
Absorption around 3300 cm⁻¹ — ν(N-H):

This corresponds to the N-H stretching vibration of the secondary amide. Secondary amides (R-NH-CO-R') show a single N-H stretch band in this region. The position and shape are characteristic of an amide NH involved in hydrogen bonding.
Absorption around 3050 to 3100 cm⁻¹ — ν(C-H unsaturated):
This corresponds to the aromatic C-H stretching vibrations. Aromatic (sp²) C-H stretches appear above 3000 cm⁻¹.
Absorptions around 2850 to 2980 cm⁻¹ — ν(CH alkyl):
These correspond to the aliphatic (sp³) C-H stretching vibrations of the methyl and methylene groups in the ethoxy group and the acetyl methyl. These appear below 3000 cm⁻¹.
Strong absorption around 1660 cm⁻¹ — ν(C=O):
This is the carbonyl stretching vibration of the amide. Amide carbonyls (known as amide I band) typically absorb around 1630 to 1680 cm⁻¹
column2: which is lower than ester or acid carbonyls due to resonance between the nitrogen lone pair and the carbonyl
column3: which reduces the double bond character of C=O.

column1: Absorptions around 1500 to 1600 cm⁻¹ — ν(C=C aromatic):
These correspond to the aromatic ring C=C stretching vibrations. Aromatic rings typically show two or three bands in the 1450 to 1600 cm⁻¹ region.
Absorption around 1450 cm⁻¹ — δas(CH₃):
This is the asymmetric bending (deformation) vibration of the methyl groups.
Absorption around 1380 to 1450 cm⁻¹ — δ(CH₂):
This corresponds to the scissoring (bending) vibration of the methylene group.
Absorption around 1200 to 1250 cm⁻¹ — ν(C-O):
This is the C-O stretching vibration of the ethoxy group (Ar-O-CH₂CH₃). Aromatic ethers show C-O stretches in the 1200 to 1275 cm⁻¹ region.
Absorption around 800 to 850 cm⁻¹ — δ(C=C-H)
column2: R-C₆H₄-R' (para):

column1: This is the out-of-plane bending vibration of the aromatic C-H bonds. The position of this band is diagnostic for the substitution pattern of the benzene ring. An absorption around 800 to 860 cm⁻¹ is characteristic of a para-disubstituted benzene ring (two adjacent hydrogen atoms on each side of the ring). This confirms the para substitution pattern.
Summary
The compound with the molecular formula C₁₀H₁₃NO₂ is identified as phenacetin (4-ethoxyacetanilide or N-(4-ethoxyphenyl)acetamide). This identification is supported by:
From ¹H NMR: A broad NH singlet
column2: two aromatic doublets consistent with para-disubstitution (2H each)
column3: a quartet for the O-CH₂ of the ethoxy group (2H)
column4: a singlet for the acetyl CH₃ (3H)
column5: and a triplet for the terminal CH₃ of the ethoxy group (3H).

column1: From ¹³C NMR: Seven distinct carbon signals showing an amide carbonyl (168 ppm)
column2: two different oxygenated/nitrogenated aromatic quaternary carbons (155 and 140 ppm)
column3: aromatic CH carbons (115 to 120 ppm)
column4: an O-CH₂ carbon (63 ppm)
column5: an acetyl CH₃ carbon (24 ppm)
column6: and a terminal CH₃ carbon (15 ppm).

column1: From IR: Characteristic absorptions for N-H stretch
column2: aromatic and aliphatic C-H stretches
column3: amide C=O stretch
column4: aromatic C=C stretches
column5: C-O ether stretch
column6: and para-disubstitution pattern in the out-of-plane C-H bending region.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;6719c431d5ad96a75c350fa5;TRUE;2

;Fluoresceins generally absorb in the visible region. To shift the wavelengths into the near-infrared
column2: modifications to their structures were necessary. Which atom was replaced
column3: and list the different examples of fluoresceins?;;;;"General Principle

column1: Fluoresceins generally absorb in the visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum. To shift the absorption wavelengths into the near-infrared region
column2: structural modifications were necessary.

column1: The key modification involves the replacement of the oxygen atom in the pyran core (the central ring of the fluorescein structure) by one of the elements from the chalcogen group (sulfur S
column2: selenium Se
column3: germanium Ge
column4: tin Sn) or by one of the elements from group 14 (carbon C
column5: silicon Si
column6: germanium Ge

column1: By substituting the bridging oxygen atom with a heavier or different atom
column2: the electronic properties of the molecule change
column3: causing the absorption and emission wavelengths to shift toward longer wavelengths (red-shifted)
column4: moving from the visible region into the near-infrared region.

column1: Examples of Modified Fluoresceins
C-Fluorescein (Carbon-substituted Fluorescein)
In this derivative
column2: the oxygen atom in the pyran core is replaced by a carbon atom. The structure retains the carboxylate group (COO⁻) on the pendant phenyl ring and the two hydroxyl-bearing ring systems characteristic of fluorescein.

column1: The excitation wavelength is 544 nm and the emission wavelength is 567 nm. This represents a modest red shift compared to standard fluorescein.
Si-Fluorescein (Silicon-substituted Fluorescein)
In this derivative
column2: the oxygen atom in the pyran core is replaced by a silicon atom. The silicon bears two chlorine substituents (Si with two Cl groups). The structure also retains the carboxylate group (COO⁻) on the pendant phenyl ring.

column1: The excitation wavelength is 591 nm and the emission wavelength is 607 nm. This represents a significant red shift compared to standard fluorescein
column2: pushing the absorption and emission further toward the red and near-infrared region.

column1: P-Fluorescein (Phosphorus-substituted Fluorescein)
In this derivative
column2: the oxygen atom in the pyran core is replaced by a phosphorus atom. The phosphorus bears additional substituents including a phenyl group (Ph) and an oxygen atom (P=O). The structure maintains the characteristic xanthene-like framework.

column1: The excitation wavelength is 627 nm and the emission wavelength is 656 nm. This represents the largest red shift among the three examples shown
column2: with both excitation and emission wavelengths now in the deep red to near-infrared region.

column1: Trend in Wavelength Shifts
Looking at the progression from C-fluorescein to Si-fluorescein to P-fluorescein:
C-Fluorescein has excitation at 544 nm and emission at 567 nm.
Si-Fluorescein has excitation at 591 nm and emission at 607 nm.
P-Fluorescein has excitation at 627 nm and emission at 656 nm.

There is a clear trend of increasing wavelengths (red shift) as the bridging atom changes from carbon to silicon to phosphorus. Each substitution pushes the absorption and emission further into the red and near-infrared region. This is due to the different electronic properties
column2: orbital energies
column3: and sizes of the substituted atoms
column4: which alter the HOMO-LUMO gap of the conjugated system and consequently shift the absorption to longer wavelengths.

column1: Summary
The atom that was replaced is the oxygen atom of the pyran core in the fluorescein structure. It can be replaced by elements from the chalcogen group (S
column2: Se
column3: Ge
column4: Sn) or from group 14 (C
column5: Si
column6: Ge
column7: Sn). Three specific examples of modified fluoresceins are C-fluorescein (carbon-substituted
column12: absorbing at 627 nm). Each successive modification shifts the absorption and emission wavelengths further toward the near-infrared region.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;671af1baed3d54e87368bca2;TRUE;2

The Starting Molecule A
The starting molecule A is pyrimidin-4(3H)-one
column2: also commonly known as 4-hydroxypyrimidine or 4-pyrimidinone.

column1: Description of the Structure
The molecule is a six-membered heterocyclic ring containing two nitrogen atoms. Specifically:
The ring is a pyrimidine ring
column2: which is a six-membered aromatic ring containing two nitrogen atoms at positions 1 and 3.

column1: At position 4 of the ring
column2: there is a carbonyl group (C=O)
column3: which makes this a pyrimidinone (a pyrimidine with a ketone/lactam functionality).

column1: The nitrogen at position 3 bears a hydrogen atom (NH)
column2: making it a secondary amine within the ring. This NH is part of the lactam (cyclic amide) functional group.

column1: The molecule can also exist in its tautomeric form as 4-hydroxypyrimidine
column2: where the carbonyl (C=O) tautomerizes to an enol form (C-OH) and the NH loses its proton. However
column3: the predominant form in most conditions is the keto form (the pyrimidinone with NH and C=O)
column4: which is the form shown in the answer.

column1: Molecular Properties
The molecular formula of pyrimidin-4(3H)-one is C₄H₄N₂O
column2: which is consistent with the information given in the exercise where compound A has a mass of 2 g corresponding to 20.81 mmol. Calculating the molar mass: 2 g divided by 0.02081 mol gives approximately 96.1 g per mol
column3: which matches the molar mass of pyrimidin-4(3H)-one (molecular weight of 96.09 g per mol).

column1: Role in the Reaction Sequence

This molecule serves as the starting material for the entire synthetic sequence. The NH group and the aromatic ring provide sites for the subsequent iodination reaction with N-iodosuccinimide (NIS) in the first step of the synthesis. The various positions on the pyrimidine ring then undergo further transformations (chlorination
column2: stannylation
column3: cross-coupling
column4: amination
column5: and oxidative cyclization) throughout the remaining steps to build up the final fused heterocyclic product.

column1: ;What is the number of steps required to obtain natural compounds of the quinazolinone type?;;;data/images/671ba17047e34cf4ed747b2c_1.png;"Overview

The image describes the potential biosynthetic pathway for the formation of natural compounds of the quinazolinone type and their further transformation into janoxepine-type compounds. The biosynthesis involves several key steps including peptide bond formation
column2: cyclization
column3: oxidation
column4: and rearrangement reactions.

column1: Starting Materials
The biosynthesis begins with two amino acid building blocks:
First amino acid: An anthranilic acid derivative
column2: which is a benzene ring bearing an amino group (NH₂) and a carboxylic acid group (CO₂H) at adjacent positions. This provides the aromatic ring portion that will become part of the quinazolinone core. It also bears an R₂ substituent.

column1: Second amino acid: A generic amino acid bearing an R₁ substituent
column2: with the standard amino acid functional groups (H₂N and CO₂H).

column1: These two amino acids serve as the fundamental building blocks for constructing the quinazolinone framework.
Step 1: NRPS-Catalyzed Peptide Bond Formation

The first step involves a Non-Ribosomal Peptide Synthetase (NRPS). NRPS enzymes are large multimodular enzymes that catalyze the assembly of peptide bonds without the need for messenger RNA or ribosomes.
The NRPS enzyme links the two amino acids together through a peptide bond (amide bond). The carboxylic acid of one amino acid reacts with the amino group of the other amino acid
column2: forming a dipeptide intermediate.

column1: The product of this step is a linear dipeptide bearing the anthranilic acid-derived aromatic ring on one end and the R₁-substituted amino acid on the other end
column2: connected through an amide bond. The molecule retains a free NH group and a CO₂H group that will participate in the subsequent cyclization.

column1: Step 2: Cyclization to Form the Quinazolinone
The dipeptide intermediate undergoes intramolecular cyclization to form the quinazolinone core structure.
In this cyclization
column2: the free amino group on the anthranilic acid portion attacks the carbonyl of the peptide bond (or the carboxylic acid) intramolecularly
column3: closing a six-membered ring. This forms the second ring of the quinazolinone system
column4: which is fused to the original benzene ring.

column1: The product is a quinazolinone-type compound
column2: which is a bicyclic structure consisting of a benzene ring fused to a pyrimidinone ring (a six-membered ring containing two nitrogen atoms and a carbonyl group). The R₁ and R₂ substituents are retained on the structure
column3: and there is a hydroxyl group (OH) present on the newly formed ring.

column1: Step 3: Oxidation to Form an Intermediate
The quinazolinone then undergoes an oxidation reaction
column2: indicated by [O] in the scheme.

column1: This oxidation modifies the quinazolinone structure
column2: likely oxidizing a carbon-nitrogen bond or introducing additional unsaturation. The product is shown as an intermediate with a modified ring system where the oxidation has created a more reactive species.

column1: This oxidized intermediate is a key branching point in the biosynthesis
column2: as it can proceed along different pathways to give different types of natural products.

column1: Step 4: Formation of Janoxepine-Type Compounds
From the oxidized intermediate
column2: further transformation leads to janoxepine-type compounds.

column1: The janoxepine structure contains a seven-membered ring (an oxepine or azepine ring) fused to the quinazolinone core. The formation of this seven-membered ring involves a ring expansion or rearrangement of the quinazolinone framework.
The R₁ and R₂ substituents are carried through to the final janoxepine product
column2: which retains the nitrogen-containing heterocyclic framework but now includes the additional seven-membered ring characteristic of the janoxepine class.

column1: Alternative Pathway: Base-Mediated Ring Opening and Further Oxidation
The lower portion of the scheme shows an alternative or additional pathway:

Base-mediated ring opening: The oxidized quinazolinone intermediate (or a related cyclic intermediate containing additional ring fusions) reacts with a base (B⁻). The base deprotonates a specific position
column2: triggering a ring-opening reaction. This breaks open one of the rings in the polycyclic system
column3: generating a linear or partially open intermediate.

column1: The ring-opened product is shown as a compound where the rings have been partially cleaved
column2: revealing free hydroxyl groups (HO) and amide bonds (NH). The R₁ and R₂ groups are still present.

column1: An isoprene-derived unit (shown as a branched alkene group with a methyl substitution
column2: characteristic of isoprenoid biosynthetic building blocks) may also be incorporated at this stage or was already present from the amino acid precursor.

column1: Further oxidation: The ring-opened intermediate undergoes another oxidation step [O]
column2: which can trigger recyclization or further structural modification. This leads to the final product
column3: which has a complex polycyclic framework bearing the R₁ and R₂ substituents
column4: multiple carbonyl groups
column5: and nitrogen-containing rings.

column1: Number of Steps
The biosynthesis of quinazolinone-type natural compounds requires the following key steps:
NRPS-catalyzed peptide bond formation (coupling of two amino acids)
Intramolecular cyclization to form the quinazolinone core
Oxidation to give a reactive intermediate
Further rearrangement or ring expansion to give janoxepine-type products (or base-mediated ring opening followed by additional oxidation for alternative products)
Therefore
column2: the minimum number of steps to obtain quinazolinone-type compounds is approximately 2 to 3 steps (NRPS coupling
column3: cyclization
column4: and oxidation)
column5: while further transformation to janoxepine-type compounds requires additional steps.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;671ba17047e34cf4ed747b2c;TRUE;1

column1: ;"The following spectrum is that of a molecule which contains nitrogen.
1. Identify the fragments whose relative abundance is greater than 10% that contain nitrogen and those that do not contain nitrogen.
2. Give the formula of these fragments.
3. Propose a structural (developed) formula for this compound.
Spectrum Data
The mass spectrum shows the following peaks with their relative abundances (AR%):
m/z = 30 with approximately 75% relative abundance
m/z = 44 with approximately 35% relative abundance
m/z = 58 with approximately 100% relative abundance (base peak)
m/z = 73 with approximately 38% relative abundance
The molecular ion peak appears to be at m/z = 73
column2: and the base peak (most abundant fragment) is at m/z = 58.";;;data/images/671e4ade104e72d40d15ae51_3.png;"Answer: Identification of a Nitrogen-Containing Compound from Mass Spectrum

column1: Initial Observations
The problem states that this is a nitrogen-containing molecule. According to the nitrogen rule in mass spectrometry
column2: there is an inversion of the parity (odd/even nature) of the fragments depending on whether they contain an odd or even number of nitrogen atoms.

column1: Base peak at m/z = 58: This is an even-numbered fragment
column2: which means it contains an odd number of nitrogen atoms (since the molecular ion is odd). This is a fragment that has lost nitrogen or retained one nitrogen.

column1: Molecular ion peak at m/z = 73: This is an odd-numbered molecular ion
column2: which indicates that the molecule contains an odd number of nitrogen atoms (according to the nitrogen rule
column3: a molecule with an odd number of nitrogen atoms will have an odd molecular mass).

column1: All the principal fragments are even-numbered (30
column4: meaning they all contain nitrogen (or are the result of rearrangements involving nitrogen).

column1: Part 1: Using the Table of Common Neutral Fragment Losses
Analyzing the neutral losses from the molecular ion at m/z = 73:
73 - 58 = 15: This corresponds to a loss of 15
column2: which means M - 15
column3: indicating the loss of a CH₃ (methyl group).

column1: 73 - 44 = 29: This corresponds to a loss of 29
column2: which means M - 29
column3: indicating the loss of CH₃CH₂ (ethyl group) or CHO (formyl group).

column1: 73 - 30 = 43: This corresponds to a loss of 43
column2: which means M - 43
column3: indicating the loss of CH₃CH₂CH₂ (propyl group)
column4: or CH₃CO (acetyl group)
column5: or HCNO. However
column6: the molecule does not contain 2N (an even number of nitrogen atoms)
column7: so the loss of HCNO is less likely.

column1: Part 2: Using the Table of Common Ion Fragments
Analyzing each fragment ion:
m/z = 30: This corresponds to CH₂NH₂⁺ (methyleneammonium ion) or NO⁺ (nitric oxide cation).
m/z = 44: This corresponds to CH₂CHO⁺ plus H
column2: or CH₃CHNH₂⁺
column3: or CO₂⁺
column4: or NH₂CO⁺
column5: or (CH₃)₃N⁺ (trimethylamine cation).

column1: m/z = 58: This corresponds to CH₃COCH₂⁺ plus H
column2: or CH₃CH₂CHNH₂⁺
column3: or (CH₃)₂NCH₂⁺
column4: or C₂H₅NHCH₂⁺ (various nitrogen-containing cations).

column1: Fragmentation Rule
The fragmentation rule states that when there is a heteroatom (O
column2: N
column3: S)
column4: the C-C bonds situated alpha to the heteroatom are easily cleaved. The charge tends to remain on the fragment containing the heteroatom. This means that in nitrogen-containing compounds
column5: cleavage occurs preferentially at the bonds adjacent to nitrogen
column6: and the nitrogen-containing fragment retains the positive charge.

column1: Part 3: Proposed Structure
The molecule contains CH₃CHNH₂ or (CH₃)₃N fragments
column2: which are proposed multiple times in the table of principal fragments. For the molecular mass to be 73
column3: the molecular formula must be C₄H₁₁N.

column1: Four possible structures with the formula C₄H₁₁N are considered:
Structure 1: Tert-butylamine. This is a nitrogen atom bearing one hydrogen (NH₂) connected to a tertiary carbon which bears three methyl groups. The structure is (CH₃)₃C-NH₂.
Structure 2: Dimethylethylamine. This is a nitrogen atom bearing two methyl groups and one ethyl group. The structure is (CH₃)₂N-CH₂CH₃.
Structure 3: A branched amine with methyl and ethyl groups connected to nitrogen
column2: with the structure CH₃CH₂-NH-CH₂CH₃ or another arrangement.

column1: Structure 4: Diethylamine. This is a nitrogen atom bearing one hydrogen (NH) and two ethyl groups. The structure is (C₂H₅)₂NH
column2: which can also be written as CH₃CH₂-NH-CH₂CH₃.

column1: Final Identification
It is difficult to decide between the possible structures. However
column2: tert-butylamine (structure 1) does not easily give fragments other than M - 15 (loss of one methyl group). It would not readily produce the fragment at m/z = 30 or m/z = 44 with significant abundance.

column1: In fact
column2: the spectrum is that of diethylamine (structure 4): (C₂H₅)₂NH.

column1: This identification is consistent with all the observed fragmentations:
The base peak at m/z = 58 (M - 15) corresponds to the loss of a methyl group from one of the ethyl chains
column2: giving CH₃CH₂NHCH₂⁺ or (C₂H₅)₂N - CH₃ fragment.

column1: The fragment at m/z = 44 (M - 29) corresponds to the loss of an ethyl group (CH₃CH₂)
column2: giving CH₃CH₂NH₂⁺ or CH₃CHNH₂⁺.

column1: The fragment at m/z = 30 corresponds to CH₂=NH₂⁺ (the iminium ion)
column2: which is formed by alpha cleavage next to the nitrogen
column3: a very characteristic fragment of secondary amines.

column1: The molecular ion at m/z = 73 confirms the molecular formula C₄H₁₁N
column2: consistent with diethylamine.";;;;Chemistry;Chemistry;671e4ade104e72d40d15ae51;TRUE;2

column1: ;"(S)-1-Iodo-1-phenylpropane A is an optically active compound. It reacts with sodium methoxide (CH₃O⁻
column2: Na⁺) to give two stereoisomers B1 and B2.

column1: The structure shows compound A with:
A phenyl group (C₆H₅)
A hydrogen atom (H)
An iodine atom (I)
An ethyl chain
attached to the chiral center
column2: with (S) configuration.

column1: The reaction is:
A reacts with CH₃O⁻
column2: Na⁺ to give B1 + B2

column1: Questions
1. Specify the type and the order of this reaction. Justify your answer.
2. Indicate
column2: by justifying through the stability of the reaction intermediate
column3: the formation of the stereoisomers B1 and B2.

column1: 3. Represent the stereoisomers B1 and B2 in projective (Cram) representation and determine their absolute configuration
column2: justifying your answer. (H (Z = 1); C (Z = 6); O (Z = 8); I (Z = 53))";;;data/images/671e8c73745919354c759204_1.png;"Answer: SN1 Reaction of an Alkyl Bromide with Hydroxide Ion

column1: Part 1: Reaction Description
The substrate is an alkyl bromide A. In the presence of the hydroxide ion (HO⁻)
column2: which has a nucleophilic character
column3: the substrate undergoes a nucleophilic substitution reaction (SN). This reaction leads to the formation of two compounds B1 and B2
column4: therefore it is a first-order reaction (SN1 mechanism).

column1: The fact that two products are formed indicates that the reaction proceeds through an SN1 mechanism rather than SN2. In an SN2 mechanism
column2: only one product would be formed (with inversion of configuration)
column3: whereas in SN1
column4: the formation of a planar carbocation intermediate allows attack from both faces
column5: leading to two stereoisomeric products.

column1: Part 2: Structure of the Reaction Intermediate and Its Stability
The substrate is a secondary or tertiary alkyl bromide bearing a phenyl group
column2: a methyl group (CH₃)
column3: and a hydrogen atom on the carbon bearing the bromine.

column1: Formation of the Intermediate
In the first step of the SN1 mechanism
column2: the C-Br bond breaks heterolytically (the bromine leaves with both bonding electrons). The bromine departs as a bromide ion (Br⁻)
column3: and a carbocation is formed at the carbon that previously bore the bromine.

column1: The intermediate is a carbocation (designated A⁺ in the scheme). This carbocation has:
A phenyl group (C₆H₅) attached to the positively charged carbon
A methyl group (CH₃) attached to the positively charged carbon
A hydrogen atom attached to the positively charged carbon
Stability of the Carbocation
The carbocation has a planar geometry. The positively charged carbon is sp² hybridized
column2: meaning it has a trigonal planar arrangement with bond angles of approximately 120 degrees. The empty p orbital is perpendicular to the plane formed by the three substituents.

column1: The carbocation is stabilized by resonance with the phenyl group. The empty p orbital on the carbocation can overlap with the pi system of the aromatic ring
column2: allowing the positive charge to be delocalized into the benzene ring. This resonance stabilization significantly lowers the energy of the carbocation
column3: making the SN1 pathway feasible.

column1: Why Two Products Form
Because the carbocation has a planar geometry
column2: the two faces of the carbocation are accessible to the nucleophile. The hydroxide ion (HO⁻) can attack from either the top face or the bottom face of the planar carbocation. Attack from one face gives product B1
column3: and attack from the other face gives product B2. These two products are stereoisomers of each other (specifically enantiomers if the original substrate was enantiopure
column4: or a pair of enantiomers if starting from a racemic mixture).

column1: Part 3: Cram Projections of B1 and B2 and Absolute Configuration
The atomic numbers given for determining priority are: H (Z = 1)
Cram Projection Representation
The carbocation intermediate A⁺ is shown in its planar form. The hydroxide ion approaches from either face of this planar carbocation.
Attack from one face gives product B1
column2: and attack from the other face gives product B2.

column1: Product B1: (1R)-1-phenylpropan-2-ol
When the hydroxide ion attacks from one specific face of the carbocation
column2: the product formed is (1R)-1-phenylpropan-2-ol.

column1: In this stereoisomer
column2: looking at the chiral center:

column1: The OH group is positioned on one side
The phenyl group and methyl group are arranged such that when assigning priorities according to the Cahn-Ingold-Prelog rules (using atomic numbers: O has Z = 8
column2: the carbon of phenyl and the carbon of methyl both have Z = 6 but differ at the next level
column3: and H has Z = 1)
column4: the sequence of decreasing priority traces a clockwise direction when the lowest priority group (H) is pointing away from the viewer.

column1: This gives the R configuration.
Product B2: (1S)-1-phenylpropan-2-ol
When the hydroxide ion attacks from the opposite face of the carbocation
column2: the product formed is (1S)-1-phenylpropan-2-ol.

column1: In this stereoisomer
column2: the same substituents are present but their spatial arrangement is the mirror image of B1. When assigning priorities and determining the direction of decreasing priority (with H pointing away from the viewer)
column3: the sequence traces a counterclockwise direction.

column1: This gives the S configuration.
Relationship Between B1 and B2

B1 and B2 are enantiomers of each other. They are non-superimposable mirror images. Since the SN1 mechanism proceeds through a planar carbocation intermediate that is equally accessible from both faces
column2: the two enantiomers are formed in approximately equal amounts
column3: resulting in a racemic mixture (50:50 mixture of R and S enantiomers).

column1: Summary
The alkyl bromide undergoes an SN1 reaction with hydroxide ion. The first step is the departure of bromide to form a planar carbocation intermediate
column2: which is stabilized by resonance with the phenyl group. The hydroxide nucleophile then attacks the planar carbocation from either face
column3: giving two enantiomeric products: (1R)-1-phenylpropan-2-ol (B1) and (1S)-1-phenylpropan-2-ol (B2). The products are represented in Cram projections
column4: and their absolute configurations are determined using the Cahn-Ingold-Prelog priority rules based on the atomic numbers of the substituents.
